dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epic beauty: cobalt mountains beneath a glowering purple fringed with pink, as if the clouds were a lid too small the earth; a cascading landscape of boulders shrouded in  deep green grass; and the blue lochs, reflecting the sky. hear a voice, husky, Scottish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will tell you of William Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A farmhouse and a large barn lie nestled in a Scottish va Riding down the roads that lead in from opposite sides ar Scottish noblemen in full regalia: eye-popping tartans,  sparkling chestplates. Even the horses are draped in scar Behind each nobleman rides a single page boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Historians from England will say I  am a liar. But history is written by  those who have hung heroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another noble rides in from the opposite side. Two more a down the road, converging on the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King of Scotland had died without  a son, and the king of England, a  cruel pagan known as Edward the  Longshanks, claimed the throne for  himself. ScotlandВ’s nobles fought  him, and fought each other, over the  crown. So Longshanks invited them to  talks of truce. No weapons, one page  only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles eye each other cautiously, but the truce holds They enter the barn, with their pages...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nestled in emerald hills are the thatched roof house and  barn and outbuildings of a well-run farm. The farmer, MAL WALLACE, and his nineteen-year-old son JOHN, both strong, tough men, are riding away from the farm. They hear hoove behind them and turn to see a boy riding after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the farmers of that shire was  Malcolm Wallace, a commoner, with  his own lands and two sons: John...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FAVOR JOHN WALLACE, the nineteen-year-old sitting easi on his horse, beside his father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLIAM, a skinny eight-year-old riding bareback, catches to his father and older brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told ya to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finished my chores. Where we goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacAndrews'. He was supposed to visit  when the truce was over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride on, over the lush hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses are all gone; the place looks deserted. UP ON HILL we see the three Wallaces, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means William. He and his elder son spur their horses.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BARN
dialogues.text: The Wallaces ride up, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacAndrews!... MacAndrews!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm finds a pitchfork, John the woodpile axe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV from within as the door opens and a widening block of sunlight illuminates the dusty shadows. Malcolm and John  Wallace step in, and are shocked to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanging from the rafters of the barn are thirty Scottish  noblemen and thirty pages, their faces purple and contort by the strangulation hanging, their tongues protruding. Malcolm stabs the pitchfork into the ground in useless an John still grips the axe as he follows his father through the hanging bodies of the noblemen to the back row, to se the one man in commoner's dress, like theirs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacAndrews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHUFFLE; John spins; William has entered the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William! Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would MacAndrews make so many  scarecrows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before his father and brother can think of anything to sa William, with a boy's curiosity, touches the spurred foot the hanged noblemen we first saw riding in. It's too soli he takes a real look at the face, and suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: R -- real!!!... Ahhhhhgggg!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to run, but knocks back into the feet of the han man behind him! In blind panic he darts in another direct and runs into another corpse, and another; the hanged men begin to swing, making it harder for William's father and older brother to fight their way to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William! William!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, worst of all, William sees the pages, boys like him hanged in a row behind their masters! Finally his father and brother reach William and hug him  tight. There in the barn, among the swinging bodies of th hanged nobles, Malcolm Wallace grips his sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderin' English bastards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cottage looks peaceful, the windows glowing yellow in the night. From outside the house we see John rise and cl the shutters of the kitchen, where men are gathered. We P UP to the upper bedroom window...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THAT BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Young William is in nightmarish sleep. He mumbles in smot terror; he twitches. We see

dialogues.speaker: HIS NIGHTMARE
dialogues.text: In the blue-grays of his dream, William stands at the doo of the barn, gazing at the hanged knights. We WHIP PAN to their faces, garish, horrible... Then one of the heads mo and its eyes open! William wants to run, but he can't get his body to respond... and the hanging nobleman, his bloa tongue still bursting through his lips, moans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will--iam...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLIAM tears himself from sleep; looking around, swallow back his tears and panic.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: A dozen strong, tough farmers have huddled. Red-headed  CAMPBELL, scarred and missing fingers, is stirred up, whi his friend MacCLANNOUGH is reluctant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace is right! We fight 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every nobleman who had any will to  fight was at that meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's up to us! We show them we  won't lie down to be their slaves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't beat an army, not with the  fifty farmers we can raise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to beat 'em, just fight  'em. To show 'em we're not dogs, but  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Wallace has snuck down and is eavesdropping from th stairs. He sees his father drip his finger into a jug of  whiskey and use the wet finger to draw on the tabletop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a camp here. We attack  them at sunset tomorrow. Give us all  night to run home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm and John have saddled horses; they are checking t short swords they've tucked into grain sacks when William comes out of the barn with his own horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, you're staying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These words from his youngest son make Malcolm pause, and kneel, to look into William's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. But it's our wits that make us  men. I love ya, boy. You stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm and John mount their horses and ride away, leavin William looking forlorn. They wave; he waves back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SCOTTISH HILLS, NEAR THE WALLACE FARM
dialogues.text: It's strangely quiet, until William and his friend HAMISH CAMPBELL, a red-headed like his father, race up the hills and duck in among a grove of trees. Breathless, gasping,  they press their backs to the tree bark. William peers ar a tree, then shrinks back and whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three, maybe more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're English soldiers, ain't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your father and brother gone,  they'll kill us and burn the farm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up to us, Hamish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish leans forward for a look, but William pulls him ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet! Here he comes, be ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait; heavy FOOTSTEPS. Then from around the edge of grove three enormous, ugly hogs appear. The boys hurling  rotten eggs. The eggs slap the snouts of the pigs, who sc as the boys charge, howling. We PULL BACK... as the sun g down on their play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys walk toward the house, beneath a lavender sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna stay with me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna have supper waitin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get those English pigs tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, we'll get 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William's face appears at the window, looking toward

dialogues.speaker: THE DISTANT HILLS
dialogues.text: of trees and heather, where there is no sign of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William has cooked stew in a pot, and now spoons up two  steaming bowls full and sets them out on the table. But h is only hoping. He looks out the window again; he is stil all alone. So he leaves a candle burning on the table bes the stew, and moves up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is silent, fog rolling around it in the dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William has been awake all night, afraid to sleep. He ris and in QUICK CUTS: he dresses; he moves down the hall, st at the door of his father's bedroom and sees the undistur bed. He moves on, passing the door of his brother's room, also unrumpled.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: He finds the two cold bowls of stew, beside the exhausted candle. He spoons up his own cold porridge, and eats alon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is in the barn loft, shoveling corn down to feed hogs, while he glimpses something coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ox cart is coming down the curving lane. Its driver is Campbell, with MacClannough walking behind it. The farmer glance up at William, their faces grim... From his perch in the loft, William sees that the neighbo have brought: the bodies of his father and brother. The c stops; Campbell, with a bandage around his left hand wher more of his fingers are now missing, studies the back of ox, as if it could tell him how to break such news. The b of the ox seems to tell him to be matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William... Come down here, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William looks away, he takes quick breaths, he looks back but the bodies are still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now surrounded by horses, wagons, and neighbors. The undertaker arrives in his hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a table the undertaker has laid out the bodies and is  preparing them. Cloths around the lower jaw and top of th head bind their mouths shut; pennies cover their eyes. Softly, William enters the shed, drawn to his father and  brother. Campbell follows him in, wanting to stop him -- what can he say now? The undertaker goes on with his work William approaches the table; the bodies don't look real him. He sees the wounds. The dried blood. The undertake pours water from a bowl and scrubs off the  blood. But the wounds remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a grave, with a headstone marked ANNE WALLACE. W INCLUDE the two new graves freshly dug beside it, and see the mourners gathered before them. The sight of the boy,  standing alone in front of the graves of his dead mother, the bodies of his father and brother are lowered with rop into the ground beside her, has all of the neighbors shak The local parish PRIEST drones mechanically in Latin. The farmers who were secretly gathered in Malcolm Wallace kitchen the previous night are now glancing at William; b no one is anxious to adopt a grieving, a rebellious boy. Behind MacClannough are his wife and two daughters; his  youngest is barely four, not half William's age; she's a  beautiful girl with long auburn hair, and she clings to h own mother's hand, as if the open graves are the mouths o death and might suck her parents in too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Restare in pacem eternis, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the final Amen, the neighbors drift from the gravesi pulling their Children along, to give William a last mome of private grief before the grave diggers cover the bodie The boy stands alone over the open graves, his heart so  shattered that he can scarcely cry; a single tear makes i way down his face. And the tiny girl feels for William in way that the adults cannot. From the ground she pulls a  Scottish thistle, moves to the softly weeping William and places the beautiful wild blossom in his hand. William looks up and their young eyes meet; her sad blue  eyes hold William's as the grave diggers cover the bodies Then a lone, mounted figure appears at the crest of the h above them. Tall, thin and angular, in black clerical gar he looks like the grim reaper. The girl hurries back to her mother's side; everyone watc in silence as the figure rides down to them. He is ARGYLE WALLACE. He looks like a human buzzard, his face craggy,  permanently furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be the relative of the  deceased... William, this is your  Uncle Argyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argyle glowers at the man, dismounts, and glares at Willi William stares up at this frightening figure. They are  interrupted by the ominous sound of approaching horses; a dozen mounted English soldiers, armed with lances, are  approaching. Argyle rattles to the priest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were wise to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers ride right in among the mourners and stare d from their saddles, haughty, menacing, their LEADER brusq

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone dead from this household?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just had a funeral, isn't that  what it means in England as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it means in England -- and in  Scotland too -- is that rebels have  forfeited their lands. We were  ambushed last night. But the Scots  dragged their dead away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother and nephew perished two  days ago, when their hay cart turned  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll just have a peek at the  wounds. (to his men) Dig 'em up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been sanctified and buried  in the holy rites of God's church,  and any hand that disturbs them now  takes on eternal damnation. So please --  do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outmaneuvered, the leader reins his horse away. Several o the farmers spit on the ground. Argyle glares at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funeral's over. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Argyle are sitting at the table, eating. Argy has laid out a proper meal, with exact place settings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that spoon, that one's for soup.  Dip away from you. And don't slurp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argyle sits down and begins to dine with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll sleep here tonight. You'll  come home with me. We'll let the  house, and the lands too; plenty of  willing neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't want your father to die either,  did ya? But it happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argyle pushes his food away; he has no appetite now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the priest say anything about  the Resurrection? Or was it all about  Judgment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in Latin, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non loquis Latinum? You don't speak  Latin? We have to fix that, won't  we? (beat) Did he give the poetic benediction?  The Lord bless thee and keep thee?  Patris Benefactum et -- (beat) ...It was Malcolm's favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argyle knows nothing about tucking a boy in bed; he stand awkwardly idle as William scrubs his face at the washstan and crawls into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argyle grunts and starts out. Then he stops, turns back,  leans down over William... and with great tenderness the  grizzled old uncle kisses his nephew on his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argyle sits by the hearth, staring at the embers. He hold the huge broadsword that belonged to his brother. He look at the handle, like a cross. He whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Lord bless thee and keep thee..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears of grief spill down the old man's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again the boy stands in the doorway of the barn, loo at the garish, hanged faces in his nightmare. Then a mang hand comes from behind him and grasps his shoulder, Willi gasps, but the hand holds him gently. He turns to see his father, and his brother! They are wounded, bloody, but th smile at him; they're alive! Weeping in joy, William reac to hug them, but his father stretches forth a forbidding  hand. William keeps reaching out helplessly. His father and bro move past him to the hanged knights. Two empty nooses are there. Before the boy's weeping eyes they put their heads into the nooses, and hoist themselves up. William's grief explodes; his tears erupt and

dialogues.speaker: HE WAKES IN HIS BEDROOM
dialogues.text: tears flooding down his face. A dream! Still upset, still grieving, he gets up and goes looking for his uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William moves down to the room where his uncle would be  sleeping. He opens the door. The bed has been slept in -- but his uncle is not there. He moves downstairs to

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: But his uncle is not there either. Then William hears a  strange, haunting sound-distant, carried by the wind. He  moves to the window and sees only moonlight. He opens the window and hears it more clearly: bagpipes. William light candle and throws open the door. Wind rushes in, blowing his candle. But he hears the pipes, louder in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is barefoot and in only his nightshirt; but the s of the pipes is growing louder. He moves through the  moonlight, drawn toward -- the graveyard! He stops as he  realizes this, then forces himself on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William moves to the top of the hill where his ancestors buried, and discovers a haunting scene: two dozen men, th farmer/warriors of his neighborhood, are gathered in kilt and among them, a core of bagpipers. The pipes wail an an Scottish dirge, a tune of grief and redemption, a melody  known to us as "Amazing Grace." Uncle Argyle has heard th and walked out too; he stands at the fringes of the  torchlight, still holding the massive broadsword. He glan down, noticing William as the boy moves up beside him. Wi whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saying goodbye in their own way --  in outlawed tartans, with outlawed  pipes, playing outlawed tunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmers file by the graveside, crossing themselves, e whispering his own private prayer. Argyle whispers, half William, and half to himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Daddy and I, we saw our own  father buried like this, dead from  fighting the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William takes the sword from his uncle, and tries to lift it. Slowly, Argyle takes the sword back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First learn to use this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps William on the temple with the tip of his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I will teach you to use this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an expert's easy fluidity, he lifts the huge sword. glistens in the torchlight. The music plays, the notes ha in the air, swirling in the Scottish breeze as if rising  towards the stars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and his uncle ride off in a farm wagon. William h a bundle of clothes in his lap, and glances at his uncle if afraid of his disapproval if he looks back. But he doe glance back just once, to see the deserted farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amid the scarlet and ermine robes of officiating lords, w gemstones sparkling everywhere, we hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve years later, Longshanks  supervised the wedding of his eldest  son, also named Edward, who would  succeed him to the throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONGSHANKS, King of England, stands in the jeweled light the ancient Abbey. Known as Longshanks because of the spi legs that make him almost seven feet tall, he has a hawk' nose and a snake's eyes, punctuating a face of distinct  cruelty. Historians of his day considered him and the lin of Plantagenets from which he came to be devil worshipers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As bride for his son, Longshanks had  chosen a relative of his rival, the  king of France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GENEVIEVE, a nineteen-year-old virgin of stupendous beaut moves down the aisle, the light in her face outshining he blindingly white wedding gown. As she reaches the altar h hands tremble, but she maintains her poise and control. She looks toward EDWARD, Prince of Wales. Pampered young surround him as his retinue. He takes her hand coldly and goes through the ceremony under his father's stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was widely whispered that for the  Princess to conceive, Longshanks  would have to do the honors himself.  That may have been what he had in  mind all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony concluding, attendants lift back the bride's veil. Her wedding day, the ultimate moment -- and Prince  Edward ignores her, to turn back to his friends. But prom by one of the sour lords, he leans over and pecks his new Princess on the cheek. For an instant, we see in her eyes that her heart is dying. But she keeps her poise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having seen to his obligations to  provide for a successor, Longshanks  set about his fondest business -- to  crush Scotland, and turn his power  against France...

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE BRITISH ISLES
dialogues.text: Longshanks' narrow finger jabs Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotland! Scot-land!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks is being listened to by his advisors, all in t outrageous splendor of royal military dress, and all deat afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French will grovel to anyone  with strength! But how will they  credit our strength when we cannot  rule the whole of our own island?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He punches the map, then sees the Princess enter softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is my son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pardon, M'lord, he asked me to  come in his stead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks' eyes expand in fury; it is frightening to see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent for him -- and the little  coward send you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I leave, M'lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he wants his queen to rule, then  you stay and learn how! I will deal  with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spins back toward his generals. Ignored, the princess  settles silently onto the cushions of the window seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobles are the key to the Scottish  door. Grant their nobles land here  in England. Give our own nobles  estates in the north. Make them too  greedy to oppose us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One OLD ADVISOR speaks up hesitantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire... Our nobles will be reluctant  to relocate. New lands mean new taxes,  and they are taxed already for our  war in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks glares at him, but takes the point. The wheels grind in his brain; his dark eyes falling on the Princess he is inspired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it's time to reinstitute an  old custom. Grant them prima noctes,  "First night." When any common girl  inhabiting their lands is married,  our lords shall have sexual rights  to her on the night of her wedding.  That should fetch just the kind of  lords we want in Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prince and a muscular young friend, PHILLIP, are stri to the waist and fencing. They pay no attention to the KNOCK, or to the Princess as she enters. She watches them they are dancing more than fencing. Edward loses his swor it clatters to the polished floor. He looks up at his wif as if angry at her for having seen his clumsiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You directed me to report to you the  moment the king's conference was  ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I did! And what was so important  about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotland. He intends --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Edward and his friend are fencing again, the clanging their blunted swords so loud that she can't hear herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He intends to grant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward loses his weapon again, and whirls on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, would you! How can I  concentrate?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...His majesty was quite keen that  you should understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All so very boring! He wants me to  learn to fight too, so let me do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For an instant, anger flares into her eyes. She glances a Edward, and at the young man with him, then lowers her ey and starts to back out. But Edward has noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, but does not raise her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you disapprove of Phillip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts his hand and draws his friend Phillip to his sid Still the Princess does not lift her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) No, M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. I said LOOK AT ME!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts her eyes. But she could not brace herself enoug for what she sees: Edward nuzzling Phillip, the prince's  bare chest to his muscular friend's bare back, both men  glistening with sweat and sexual excitement. The Princess's eyes quiver... but she does not look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, my flower, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I had thought that... I was  loathsome to you. Perhaps I am. If I  may be excused, M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to leave, as quietly as she came. But her husb calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, m'Lady, it is my royal  responsibility to breed. And I assure  you, when the time comes, I shall...  manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door softly, on her husband and his lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in Edinburgh were gathered the  council of Scottish nobles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picturesque heart of Scotland, with its CASTLE on a f tale plateau above the Firth of Forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles are gathered around a huge table. They rise at the entrance of young ROBERT THE BRUCE, a handsome young  man, full of intelligence and power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among these was Robert, the 17th  Earl of Bruce, a leading contender  for the crown of Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert strides to his seat in the center of the table, an the others settle in respectfully. MORNAY, another young  warrior, gives him a bow, as does CRAIG, a grizzled noble

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Robert, we are honored --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father hears that Longshanks has  granted prima noctes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly meant to draw more of his  supporters here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Balliol clan has endorsed the  right, licking Longshanks' boots so  he will support their claim to the  throne. If we make a show of  opposition, the commoners will favor  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too soon to step out alone. My  father believes we must lull  Longshanks into confidence, by neither  supporting his decree nor opposing  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wise plan. And how is your father?  We have missed him at the council.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strained his leg so that it pains  him to ride. But he sends his  greetings -- and says that I speak  for all the Bruces. And for Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flutes and dancing; laughter and garlands; village famili have gathered for a wedding celebration -- we see the hap bride and groom. Farmers cart in fresh bread and hoops of cheese; villagers arrive with casks of beer or strings of smoked fish. And watching the people are ubiquitous English soldiers,  battlescarred veterans with missing eyes and ears. Riding along the road comes William Wallace. Grown now, a man. He sits his horse as if born there, his back straigh his hands relaxed on the reins. He has a look of lean, ri power. He looks dangerous. And the soldiers notice him, nudging each other as he pas He carries a dead wild goose hanging across his saddle; h stops his horse at the edge of the clearing and surveys t scene. Farmers are roasting a pig; women are comparing  handiwork; young men are tossing huge stones in the  traditional Highland games -- and everyone is noticing  William's arrival, especially the farm women with daughte of marriageable age. Among those watching William arrive is Campbell, grown ol now; and with his old rebel friend, MacClannough. William dismounts and ties his horse to a willow. One of the Engl SOLDIERS shoves William from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey boy! You hunt this bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William's eyes fix themselves on the soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against the law for Scots to  own bows. You shot this bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His buddies, enjoying their role as intimidators, grab th bird and begin to search it for evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hit it in the head. With a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't believe that -- but they can't find any punctu wound on the bird. William reaches his hand out for the r of the bird. The soldiers drop it onto the ground. Slowly, William picks it up, and heads into the clearing. The farmers watch him come. Among those noticing William's arrival, but pretending no to, is MARION MacCLANNOUGH, grown now into a stunning you woman; her long auburn hair reminds us of those years lon ago; she wears it the same way, straight and full down he back. Her dress is plain, like the grass that surrounds a wildflower. She's the most beautiful girl in the village, maybe in all of Scotland, and the soldiers who hassled Wi notice her too. William reaches the food table and contributes his goose the feast. FARM WOMEN eye him; he nodes to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz MacDougal. You look well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...William? It's William Wallace,  back home! -- Have you met my  daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The daughter mentioned is missing teeth. William nods to  her. It's impossible for him to giver her a smile as brig as her hopes, and she lowers her head in disappointment. then raises her face in surprise as William takes her han and gives her a respectful bow. He moves away from the table, passing through the crowd l a stranger. Then he glances toward the knot of girls. He  sees Marion. She sees him, then looks away. Do they remem each other? He moves toward her; she is shy, her eyes  downcast, but then she raises them and looks at him. They move closer and closer together. Just as they are ab to reach each other, a huge round stone THUMPS to the ear at Williams' feet. He looks up to see one of Marion's suitors -- the broad,  muscled young man who has just tossed the stone in Willia way. Now everybody's looking to see how William will hand the challenge. He tries to move around, but the guy cuts off. Then William thinks he recognizes the big red-head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is his old friend, but Hamish won't admit it, or be pu off from the challenge. He points to the huge stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Test of manhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blocks him) Call it a test of soldiery, then.  The English won't let us train with  weapons, so we train with stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The test of a soldier is not in his  arm. It's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps his temple. Hamish stretches out his hand, as if show William something in his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sudden movement, he slams his fist into William's  jaw, dropping him. A few men move to interfere, but Campb MacClannough, and the other farmers who are the true lead here, stop their neighbors from interrupting. Hamish stan over William, waiting for him to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A contest, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William stands and hoists the huge stone, eighteen inches diameter. Straining with the effort, he lugs the stone to the line scratched in the rocky field. Beyond the line ar the muddy dents from previous tosses. William takes a run and heaves the stone. It flies past the other marks in th field; people are impressed. William looks at Hamish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still say this is no test. A  catapult can throw a stone farther  than a man can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish walks out, lifts the stone, and lugs it back to th line. He takes a run and heaves with a great groan! The s flies, passing William's mark by a couple of feet. People laugh and whistle. William nods, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do it when it matters? As it  matters in battle? Could you crush a  man with that throw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could crush you like a roach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William walks to the dent made by Hamish's throw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do it. Come, do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish scowls at William, at everybody watching. He lifts the stone and carries it back to the line. William stands calmly. Hamish backs up for his run. William yawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll move

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish backs up a few more feet, for a longer run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tired, he should get a longer  run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William seems completely unafraid. He leans down, picks u small smooth stone and tosses it up in the air casually. Stung by this show of calm, Hamish takes furious run, and heaves! The stone flies through the air, just misses Will head, and buries itself halfway into the earth behind him William never flinches. The people cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave show!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish is miffed; it's like William won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I threw longer than last time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ox is strong, but not clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ox is stupid enough to just stand  in one place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William turns, walks double the distance Hamish threw, an turns and hurls the rock he holds! It whistles through th air, hits Hamish in the forehead, and drops him like a sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody cheers and laughs! They surround William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine display, young Wallace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William takes a tankard of ale from a farmer, walks over tosses the cold liquid into Hamish's face; he wakes, and, his eyes uncrossing, accepts William's hand, pulling him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should'a remembered the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grinning, they embrace. MUSIC plays, the dancing begins. William walks to the knot of young ladies... but passes  Marion, and moves to the girl with the missing teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you honor me with a dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's thrilled to accept; they begin to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've taken over your father's farm? (beat) They say he died long ago. Fighting  the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died in an accident, with my  brother. Their cart turned over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The musicians interrupt their playing; a group of heavily armed horsemen, with banners and flying colors, ride up,  reining their horses into the middle of the celebration. the middle of the group is an English NOBLEMAN; he is gra in his fifties, and stops in front of the BRIDE and groom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come to claim the right of  prima noctes. As the lord of these  lands, I will bless this marriage by  taking the bride into my bed on the  first night of her union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart, father of the BRIDE, lunges forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, by God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horsemen point their lances at the unarmed Scots -- w see that the English soldiers from the village have moved the edge of the gathering, as if to dare any resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my noble right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even unarmed, Stewart is about to attack -- but the bride intervenes. She grabs her father and whispers to him. She moves to her husband and does the same. Holding back tear she allows herself to be pulled up behind one of the hors Marion MacClannough is looking on, sobered by her friend' courage and sickened by her fate -- and Marion is even mo unsettled as she notices that one of the soldiers, a  particularly nasty looking brute with a scarred face, is  leering at her. William Wallace sees this too. The noble and his escorts ride away, and as they do it be to rain. The celebration destroyed, the Scots gather the  food and disperse to their homes. But Wallace remains,  standing in the downpour, keeping his thoughts to himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmhouse looks lonely and forlorn. William stands at the open door, and gazes out at the rain; it leaks on him through his roof; he doesn't seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thatched cottage, lit with a cozy fire, beneath the rai A hand KNOCKS on the door, and MacClannough opens it to f William, on a horse! MacClannough frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir. May I speak with  your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacClannough shoulders up beside her husband, and Ma appears behind her scowling parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion... Would you like to go for a  ride on this fine evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy's insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good Scottish weather, Madam,  the rain is fallin' straight down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She absolutely may not, she'll --  Marion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion has grabbed a cloak off the back of the door; she  runs out to hop up behind William, and they gallop away.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIDE
dialogues.text: William and Marion race along the heather, up and down hi through swollen streams. The rain stops, as the sun sets; the Scottish mists lift, revealing stunning natural beaut William stops the horse and they look out over it all  together. He speaks, without turning to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father doesn't like me, does  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not you. He dislikes that you're  a Wallace. He just says... the  Wallaces don't seem to live for very  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for accepting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for inviting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll invite you again, but your mother  thinks I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are. And I'll come again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lingers; he wants to say something, or maybe he just  doesn't want the moment to end. Finally he spurs the hors

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the door. William hops off the horse and reach up to help her down the moment she touches the ground, th look into each other's eyes... but the door is snatched o so quickly by her mother that there is not time for a kis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks her closer to the door. They turn and look at ea other again. She waits for him to kiss her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still hesitates; he isn't going to kiss her. She star in, but he grabs her hand. And into it he puts something has taken from his pocket; it is wrapped in flannel. He h on his horse, glances at her, and gallops away. She stands in the open doorway; she looks down at what he left her. She unwraps the flannel; it is a dried thistle, the one she gave him years before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is re-thatching the roof of his barn, when he hea riders approaching, and looks down to see that it is  MacClannough, backed by Campbell and Hamish. Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Wallace --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I know it was strange of me to  invite Marion to ride last night. I  assure you, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacClannough's daughter is another  matter. We come to fetch you to a  meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The secret kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William goes back to repairing his roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father was a fighter. And a  patriot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who my father was. I came  back home to raise crops. And, God  willing, a family. If I can live in  peace, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell shakes his head and reins his horse away, with  Hamish. MacClannough lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can keep your intention to  stay out of the troubles, you may  court my daughter. If you break your  intention, I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacClannough rides away. William sits down on the roof, a looks out at the graves of his father and brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the half-timbered house, William stands in the sh of moonlight and tosses a pebble against the wooden upper window. Marion opens the shutters and slips out onto the  vines, dropping into William's arms. Giggling, suppressing laughter, they run to the trees...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTISH HIGHLANDS
dialogues.text: Hand in hand through the heather they run, silhouettes al a ridge, their breath blowing silver clouds in the moonli the Scottish wind whipping through their hair. They stop at a grove at the edge of a precipice, overlook a loch gleaming in the moonlight. So beautiful it's sacre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been here before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some nights. I have dreams. Mostly  dreams I don't want. I started riding  at night to fill up my mind so that  when I did sleep I'd dream only of  the ride and the adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You don't choose your dreams.  Your dreams choose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. They kiss suddenly, so long and hard tha they tumble into the heather, rolling, devouring each oth Through their passion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want... to marry you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... accept your proposal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not just saying it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I won't give you up to any  nobleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping) You scare me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to scare you. I want to  be yours, and you mine. Every night  like this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This night is too beautiful to have  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be with you, like this.  Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion moves through the market. English soldiers admire as she walks. She stops, looking at white lace and cloth. William casually passes, poking a note in her basket. Sub she withdraws his note, and reads:

dialogues.speaker: HIS NOTE
dialogues.text: Tonight. By the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion slips out of the house and runs to the trees, wher William waits with horses. She fetches a bundle she's sta in the crook of a tree, and they mount and ride off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church is at the base of the precipice, beside the lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ancient Gaelic place of worship has been destroyed b the occupying army, and yet it looks devoutly holy this w lit only by candles and moonlight through the open roof. village PRIEST whom we saw at the wedding celebration is  waiting at the altar. Marion steps into the confessional, William moves to the altar and kneels in prayer. Marion emerges; she's changed into the wedding dress she  made from the cloth she bought. William stands and watche her float down the aisle; his whole life was worth this  moment. Together, the two lovers turn to the priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have come to pledge, each to the  other, before Almighty God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From within his shirt, William withdraws a strip of cloth woven in his family tartan. He and Marion each lift a han to the priest, and he binds their wrists with the cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will love you my whole life. You  and no other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her dress she takes a handmade handkerchief, embroid with a thistle to look like the one she first gave him th years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I you. You and no other. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Priest waits for them to go on, but neither can; they too taken with emotion, looking at each other. The Priest intones holy phrases...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agus bhayd lauch... The Lord bless  and keep thy love, now and forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lovers kiss. As they break their embrace, a figure  carrying something dark and spiky appears at the broken d of the church, and William spins as if to attack, but the Priest catches his arm; they see the man carries bagpipes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust him -- or I'd'a killed him  me'self. A weddin' needs pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piper begins to play, and the tune from his primitive chanter is wispy, ethereal, beautiful. The lovers look in each other's eyes, as the single melody of the pipes merg into a swell of music, UNDERSCORING MONTAGE William and Marion ride the path to the top of the precip where, in the shelter of the grove, they spend their  honeymoon. The MUSIC CONTINUES as, still sweaty from thei love-making, he returns her to her house just before dawn She waves from her window, as William rides away, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Market Day in the village, busy with Highlanders,  merchants of all kinds, and a few special attractions lik jugglers and fortune tellers. Marion moves along a table  full of flowers and fruit... William, concealed behind ha baskets, watches her unseen, savoring the beauty of his  beloved, bathing his soul in the sight of her. Then she l up and spots him, her smile sudden and luminous, before s remembers to conceal it. He moves up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush. It's only been a day. (beat) And it's seemed like forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents are growing suspicious! I  can't keep meeting you every night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playfully he pokes his finger under the collar of her dre pulling up the strip of checked cloth he gave her at thei wedding, which she now wears hidden around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tucking in the cloth strip, she hurries away, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN ENGLISH SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: They spot Marion moving through the fair, glowing, beauti The soldiers smirk at each other; as Marion passes, one o them grabs her wrist. It's the soldier with the scar, the one who's been staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going... lass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second drunken SOLDIER pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you marry my friend here?  Then I'll take the first night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scarred soldier pulls Marion into his big arms; she s him away with surprising strength, and he staggers back, the laughter of his friends. Then he snatches her again a kisses her hard on the lips. She breaks free and SLAPS him fiercely, hard enough to dr blood from his mouth. Tasting the trickle, he slings her  down against sacks of grain, and the soldiers are all ove her, pinning her down, ripping her clothes, a full scale  public gang rape. As the townspeople try to move in the t soldiers waiting their turn at Marion pull their knives,  keep them townspeople back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch, who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams his mouth down against hers for a long, awful ti comes up clawing at her dress to rip it from her body... is hit in the face by a rock thrown at great speed! It takes a moment for the other soldiers to realize what  just happened, and in that instant William is on them. He wrenches one soldier's arm in a direction it was never me to go, breaking the elbow, separating the shoulder, and  slinging the howling soldier into his comrades. Two of the soldiers leap at William, swinging their short swords; William ducks, knocking their ale cask into their knees; William lifts the whole table where they were sitt and slams it into the faces of two more attackers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shouts to warn him that the scarred soldier, now  bloodyfaced, has recovered from the rock and is behind Wi with a knife. William sidesteps the first thrust, snatche leg from the shattered table and crushes the man's skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace Wallace! William Wallace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's no time for celebration. There's blood and al everywhere, and the fallen soldiers are yelling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebels! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORE SOLDIERS hear the call and come running, reinforceme converging from all over the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, William! Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sees the horse that pulled the flower cart and throw Marion up onto its back. He slaps the horse's rump and it plunges with Marion into the twisting village lanes. Will darts off through the crowd, as the MAGISTRATE and more o his soldiers arrive -- dozens of them! William pauses out in the central street of the village,  just long enough to be sure they've spotted him, and dart into a side lane in the opposite direction Marion went;  William weaves through the narrow streets of the medieval town, knocking over baskets, jumping carts. As the soldiers stumble after him, the Magistrate looks d at his mangled soldiers. The one with the ruptured arm is lying in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What girl?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...on horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl on the horse! Stop her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shout rings through the village; Marion hears it, and when she sees more soldiers at the far end of the lane sh trying to take out of town, she urges the horse into an e narrower back alley. She sees a clear route to freedom... But the flock of pigeons pecking on the scraps thrown the behind the shops rise into the horse's face with a sudden thrashing of wings, and the horse shies against a wall. Marion controls him, but a flap of her ripped dress has c on a crude nail, and as the frightened horse lunges forwa again, she is pulled off its bare back, her dress catchin and ripping at the same time, dropping her hard.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: reaches the edge of the town and slips into the trees by river; the soldiers are running every which way, but they lost him. Thinking Marion's made it too, William heads de into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TOWN, MARION
dialogues.text: recovers; her dress has torn free! She starts to get up; the soldiers' pikes appear over her, and the magistrate l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is the little whore he was  fighting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William moves into the shelters of the trees, expecting t see Marion. He doesn't. He listens; only the rustling of wind through the treetops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, except the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion is thrown into a chair and her arms are bound with oak staff behind her elbows. She and two dozen soldiers a in the tavern the English have commandeered. The Magistrate is a battlescarred veteran, a brutal pragm angry with his CORPORAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Scot buggers six of us? Hell to  pay when that gets round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burn the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he is free. You never catch 'em  in the Highlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies Marion, her mouth now stuffed with burlap. He  notices the strip of cloth around her neck, and touches t weave curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clans weave that cloth in their own  patterns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why is this strip concealed? (beat) He fought for you, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magistrate and his men bring Marion into the village  center, and tie her to a post of the well. The townspeopl don't want to be near the soldiers, but they hang on the  fringes of the square, too curious to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An assault on the king's soldiers is  the same as assaulting the king!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at Marion, her mouth bound, her eyes defian He jerks out his dagger and slices Marion's throat! Her eyes spring open like a doe's; then she sags, dead. T townspeople are speechless; even some of the soldiers are shocked. The Magistrate turns calmly to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Let this scrapper come to me.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE GROVE AT THE PRECIPICE
dialogues.text: From a distance, we see Hamish approaching the grove, the same one where he and William played as boys. Hamish move reluctantly, forcing himself forward; as he reaches the g William appears, hurrying out to him. We STAY IN THE LONG SHOT, seeing William asking anxiously for any news, and seeing Hamish's great shoulders as he t him something that makes William step backwards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a barrier across the main road into the center of the  village are twenty professional soldiers, entrenched, ful armed -- bows, pikes, swords. They hear A HORSE'S SNORT..

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE, ON HIS HORSE
dialogues.text: He has stopped, rock still. The soldiers hush; there is  something unsettling about this man alone, staring at the twenty of them, as if to steel himself for the butchery. Wallace raises his sword, screams... and charges!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FAVOR WALLACE'S SUBJECTIVE POV: the barrier as his hor pounds toward it, the faces of the enemy soldiers with th eyes white with fear... They stand to shoot at him with t bows; the arrows WHISH toward the lens, fly past... The arrows tear through Wallace's clothes, but don't catc his flesh. He charges on; his horse LEAPS the barrier as  Wallace simultaneously swings the broadsword -- and he's  more than an expert: the tip, at the end of a huge arc, n breaks the sound barrier and the blade bites through the  corporal's helmet, taking off the upper half of his head! The soldiers try to rally, to shoot him in the back as hi horse leaps over them. One of them has sighted William's  back... But Hamish and his father crash into them! It's a wild fight; old Campbell takes an arrow through the shoul but keeps hacking with his sword; Hamish batters down two men -- and more Scots arrive! They overwhelm the soldiers

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE RACES THROUGH THE VILLAGE
dialogues.text: He dodges obstacles in the narrow streets -- chickens, ca barrels. Soldiers pop up; the first he gallops straight o the next he whacks forehand, like a polo player; the next chops down on his left side; every time he swings the  broadsword, a man dies. Wallace gallops on; his farmer neighbors, and people from the village, follow in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magistrate hears the APPROACHING SHOUTS. He and thirt more of his men are barricaded around the village square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look surprised! We knew he'd  bring friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The see Wallace gallop into sight; but he stops, then hea down a side street. The Magistrate and his men don't like this; where did he Which way will he come from? And then they hear the horse and see the other Scots, at the head of the main street. soldiers unleash a volley of arrows at them. They are loading to fire again when Wallace runs in -- on foot! -- and cuts down two soldiers! The other Scots char The startled soldiers break and run in every direction. The Magistrate, abandoned, runs too. Wallace pursues. Not far along a twisting lane, the bulky Magistrate falte He turns to fight, and Wallace slashes away his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I beg you... mercy!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TOWN SQUARE
dialogues.text: As the Scots see Wallace, they break off pursuing the Eng soldiers and stop to watch; dragging the Magistrate by hi hair, Wallace hauls him back into the village square, sla him against the well, and stands over him with heaving lu and wild eyes, staring at Marion's murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Mercy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace's eyes shift, falling on

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIN OF BLOOD
dialogues.text: Marion's blood, in a dark dry splash by the wall of the w the stain dripping down onto the dirt of the street. Wall spins, jerks back the Magistrate's head, and cuts his thr with the sword.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SCOTS
dialogues.text: Silenced by what they've just seen and done. On old Campb face is a look of reverence, and awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Grace to God, lads. We've just  seen the coming of the Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William staggers a few steps, and collapses to his knees. And then not just the Scottish farmers but the townspeopl too begin a strange, Hi-Lo chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AHHHHHHH-UHHHHHH! AHHHHHH-UHHHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William's wild eyes slowly regain their focus. And there the dirt beside the well, he sees the severed cloth strip gave to Marion, now stained with her blood. He lifts it,  crushes it in his hand, as the Highlanders chant for war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The villagers are still excited by what just happened; at the blacksmith's forge, men tend to Campbell's wound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pour it straight into the wound. I  know it seems a waste of good whiskey,  but indulge me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They obey, then take a glowing poker from the fire and ru it through Campbell's shoulder, where the arrow went. The is a terrible SIZZLE, and Campbell reacts to the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Now that'll clear your sinuses,  lads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell looks down at his left hand. His thumb is missin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well bloody Hell, look at this! Now  it's nothing but a fly swatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace is sitting alone nearby, staring at nothing. Hami moves over and puts a hand on his shoulder. Wallace looks his friend, and looks away; killing the Magistrate did no bring Marion back. SHOUTS of alarm: ARMED MEN are coming! The farmers scramb for their weapons, ready to fight; even Campbell jumps up but what they see coming out of the darkness are twenty m farmers, with hayhooks, knives, axes, anything they could find for weapons. Their leader is MacGREGOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacGregor -- from the next valley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacGregor leads his men into the circle of rebels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard about what was happenin'.  And we don't want ya thinkin' ya can  have your fun without us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home. Some of us are in this, I  can't help that now. But you can  help yourselves. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have no homes left when the  English garrison at the castle comes  through to burn us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furious preparations: armorers pound breastplates, hone  spears, grind swords in a shower of sparks. The garrison led by BOTTOMS, the English lord who claimed the right of prima noctes. Now he shouts to his scurrying soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gather the horses! Align the infantry! (grabs a man) Ride to the Lord Governor in Stirling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him that I will hang five rebels for every good  Englishman killed! FORM FOR MARCH! The troops begin to scramble into the courtyard. At the s time, the messenger gallops to the gate and nods for the  keepers to open it. They pull up the chains and the heavy gate rises. The messenger spurs his horse to gallop throu and is hit in the chest with an axe! The Scots, hidden just outside the gate, come pouring thr led by Wallace! Arrows pick soldiers from their perches,  Scots drop over the wall; the surprise is so complete tha it's over almost without a fight. Lord Bottoms looks arou in confusion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop them... Don't let... Align...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scots drag Lord Bottoms off his horse; an arrow in a flex bow jabs right up to his eye, the archer ready to drive t shaft through Bottom's eye socket and into his brain; but Wallace's hand closes on the archer's fingers -- and Bott sees that the archer at the other end of the arrow shaft none other than the Highland farmgirl he forced into his on her wedding night. Beside her is her husband, holding scythe, red with English blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your way somewhere, M'lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdering bloody bandit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point of Wallace's sword jumps beneath the Lord's chi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is William Wallace. I am no  bandit who hides his face... Find  this man a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The green eyes of the defiled highland bride flash fire. William takes his hand from her bow and looks at her, gri for Marion in his eyes; for the sake of that she does not release the string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish extends the reins of the Lord's thoroughbred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this horse. That one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to a bony nag hitched next to a glue pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today we will spare you, and every  man who has yielded. Go back to  England. Tell them Scotland's  daughters and her sons are yours no  more. Tell them Scotland is free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Scots cheer, Wallace throws Lord Bottoms onto the  nag's back and slaps the horse's rear. IT shambles away,  followed by the English survivors, as the Scots chant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace, Wal-lace, Wal-lace!...

dialogues.speaker: A GRAVESTONE
dialogues.text: The marker is carved with the name MARION MacCLANNOUGH, a beneath her name A THISTLE is chiseled into the stone. Bagpipes wail like banshees and the Priest who married Ma and William now mutters ancient prayers as her body, wrap in burial canvas, is lowered into the earth, under the sa eyes of those who just fought in the battle. Opposite William stands old MacClannough; he stares acros the open hole that accepts the body of his daughter, his  eyes full of pain, and then staggers away. Wallace kneels at the graveside in unspeakable grief. Fro within his shirt he withdraws the embroidered handkerchie she gave him, and the bloodstained strip of cloth he gave her. He places the strip over her heart, and as the  gravediggers fill the hole her returns the handkerchief t its spot over his own heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Edward is in his garden, playing the medieval vers of croquet with his friend. The Princess, ignored, sits  watching. Longshanks marches through the game, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scottish rebels have routed Lord  Bottoms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear. This Wallace is a bandit,  nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks slaps his son, knocking him down among the col balls and wickets. Everyone gasps, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weak little coward! Stand up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks jerks him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to France to press our rights  there! I leave you to handle this  little rebellion, do you understand?  DO YOU?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks grabs his son by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And turn yourself into a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king leaves. The friends of the humiliated Prince hur to him and lift him; as the Princess moves to him too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps her! Her personal guards, Frenchmen in distincti uniforms, jump from their seats at the edge of the garden but the Princess raises a hand to show she needs no  assistance, and curtseys to Edward, who shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convene my military council!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Edward marches off with his entourage, NICOLETTE, a  beautiful raven-haired Handmaiden, rushes to the Princess who is wobbly, hurt more than she let show. Nicolette whi to her in French, with subtitles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say this Wallace killed thirty  men to avenge the death of his woman.  I hope your husband goes to Scotland.  Then you'll be a widow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce is in bed with a young Nordic beauty wit vacant blue eyes. She drowses; but the lovemaking has not defused the restlessness of Robert's spirit. He lies on h stomach, turned away from her on the bed. Stirring, she k his neck; but he doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to please you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he is numb as she nuzzles him again. She sags back, a he still stares away, lost in thought. Realizing her hurt he explains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Lanark village, the king's soldiers  killed a girl. Her lover fought his  way through the soldiers and killed  the magistrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rebelled. He rebelled. He acted.  He fought! Was it rage? Pride? Love?  Whatever it was, he has more of it  than I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) You might have lied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too arrogant to lie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT THE BRUCE
dialogues.text: On his FACE as he moves grimly up a dark castle staircase He follows a servant who carries a candle against the glo They reach a door, which the servant unlocks. Young Rober takes the candle, and enters --

dialogues.speaker: A DARKENED ROOM
dialogues.text: Robert wills himself forward, and places the candle on a  table in the center of the room. A SHUFFLE in the dark; t moving into the light is a LEPER whose once-noble feature are decaying with the disease. Isolated in his disfigurat he looks at his visitor -- his son -- with the eyes of th condemned. Young Robert forces himself not to look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father. A rebellion has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commoner named William Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commoner? So no one leads Scotland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man thinks, and points a half finger at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will embrace this rebellion.  Support it, from our lands in the  north. I will gain English favor by  condemning it and ordering it opposed  from our lands in the south. Whichever  way the tide runs, we will rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Wallace. He doesn't even have a  knighthood. But he fights with  passion, and he is clever. He inspires  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You admire him. Uncompromising men  are easy to admire. He has courage.  So does a dog. But you must understand  this: Edward Longshanks is the most  ruthless king ever to sit on the  throne of England, and none of us,  and nothing of Scotland, will survive  unless we are as ruthless, more  ruthless, than he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Bruce rises heavily, and moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press your case to the nobles. They  will choose who rules Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a last long look at his father, Robert leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Troops ride through the countryside, intimidating and  questioning civilians; all refuse to talk. -- Wallace's house burns, as soldiers dig up the graves o his father and brother, and scatter their bones to dogs. -- The English search through the woods, finding nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Hamish ride, to see the damage. They find the smoking ruins, and the defiled family graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, William... I am so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is struck by an awful, urgent thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open on Marion's grave, with the thistle-carved marker looking peaceful; but up the hill in the underbrush, Engl soldiers wait in ambush. Edgy, they perk up at the sound muffled hoofbeats -- then their eyes bug as a cloaked fig Wallace -- suddenly looms up behind them, galloping and  swirling fire! He hurls burning torches into the clustere soldiers, setting some of them on fire! MEANWHILE, HAMISH has crawled to Marion's grave and is di frantically. The new dirt parts easily and he pulls the  shrouded body out, cringing with the effort. MORE SOLDIERS rush from behind the rocks at the far side the graveyard. Wallace charges them, driving them back. H grabs the reins of Hamish's horse, hidden among trees, an gallops to him. Hamish hands the shrouded body up to William and bounds i the saddle of his own horse. They spur the horses and rid away, William clutching Marion's shrouded body to his che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William dismounts, stretching the body gently on the grou Hamish dismounts too, with the spade he used to dig up th old grave. He sees the emotion on William's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait... back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish, I... thank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish puts a hand on his friend's shoulder, then quietly leads the horses away. William starts to dig...

dialogues.speaker: LATER IN THE GROVE
dialogues.text: William sits looking at the new grave, covered with leave completely hidden. He touches his hand to the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish is waiting as William comes out of the grove. Ther is nothing to say. They mount their horses and ride away, the MUSIC of William and Marion's love haunts us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace and his inner circle hare huddled around a small  fire. Other highlanders guard the perimeters. Old Campbel is lovingly honing the broadswords to razor edges and sha a whiskey jug with Hamish, who stares at the fire. Wallac is using a stick to draw diagrams in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do when Longshanks sends  his whole northern army against us?  They have heavy cavalry. Armored  horses, that shake the very ground.  They'll ride right over us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a loss, Wallace looks up at the sky. HE SEES: the tree stretching into the night like spikes to skewer the stars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We make spears. A hundred spears.  Fourteen feet long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volunteers coming in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look to see a half dozen new volunteers being led in blindfolded. When the guides remove the blindfolds, the n recruits see Wallace and rush to him, bowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
