dialogues.text: William Wallace? We have come to  fight and die for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up, man, I'm not the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Faudron! My sword is yours! And  I brought you this tarta --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reaches into his cloak, both Hamish and Campbell  instantly draw their swords and put the points to his nec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We checked them for arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully, Faudron pulls out a beautiful tartan scarf, an replaces Wallace's tattered old one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your family tartan! My wife  wove it with her own hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank her for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud voice interrupts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him? That can't be William Wallace!  I'm prettier than this man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at a slender, handsome young man, STEPHEN, is talking to himself -- or more accurately, seems to lis to some unheard voice, then answer it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Father, I'll ask him! (to William) If I risk my neck for you, will I  get a chance to kill Englishmen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your Poppa a ghost -- or do you  converse with God Almighty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In order to find his equal, and  Irishman is forced to talk to God. (quickly) Yes, Father!... (to Wallace) The Almighty says don't change the  subject, just answer the fookin'  question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insane Irish --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen whips a dagger from his sleeve and puts it at  Campbell's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart enough to get a dagger past  your guards, old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace jerks his sword to the Irishman's throat, and gri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my friend, Irishman. And the  answer's yes. You fight for me, you  kill the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen grins, and happily tucks away the dagger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent! Stephen is my name. I'm  the most wanted man on the Emerald  Isle. Except I'm not on the Emerald  Isle of course, more's the pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A common thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patriot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace shakes his head and moves back to the fire, as th sentries take the newcomers to find their own spaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of English light cavalry -- a hundred riders --  moves through the picturesque beauty of the Highlands. English LORD DOLECROFT is in command, wearing a hat with pompous white plume. UP AHEAD, the English SCOUT sees fiv Scots, including Hamish, walking out of the forest. The S run; the Scout rides back to Dolecroft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotsmen, Sire! Headed west!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've blundered at last! After  them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English force charges off. Hamish and his men changed direction but the English spot them crossing a hilltop an ride after them. The Scots run for their lives; the Engli horses gallop. The Scots run down one slope, up another; English follow, find their horses stumbling, and see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a bog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, it's firm this way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as they move toward the firm ground, fifty Scots appe on the crest of the hill. Hamish leads them, smiling. Dolecroft wheels and looks to his rear; Wallace appears t with fifty more, and more Scots appear to the left and ri of the English, who are surrounded in the bog. Too late,  Dolecroft realizes his blunder. Wallace lifts his broadsw screams, and leads the charge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots are moving through deep woods; they are laden w the booty they took from the English cavalry: extra weapo clothing, food -- and one man even wears the late Dolecro plumed hat. Wallace is leading them, traveling with his h sheathed broadsword across his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop here and rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They collapse to the leaves and loam, greedily squeezing  water from sheep belly canteens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD PICKERING, English commander, is handed news of the  disaster. He reads the message, and pales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another ambush! My God! ...What about  our infiltrator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has already joined them, M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is high above the Scots, encamped for the night. Most everyone is sleeping, but William sits leaning again a tree, lost in lonely thoughts. Suddenly William freezes shaft of moonlight illuminates a cloaked woman standing t feet ahead of him. Something about her is familiar -- and then she pulls off the hood, revealing her auburn hair,  cascading in the moonlight... It is Marion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion! Is... is it you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy explodes on his face, and he runs to her, but stops b he touches her, as if she might evaporate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are. And you must wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to wake. I want to stay  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I with you. But you must wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you so much! I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, William. Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, William!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William clutches at Marion, but his arms can't enclose he

dialogues.speaker: HE WAKES
dialogues.text: lying on his new tartan, in camp, with Hamish shaking him William's arms clutched empty to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William! Hounds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace jumps up, hearing the DISTANT BARKING that alarme Hamish. Stephen, the new Irish recruit, races up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must run in different directions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't split up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used hounds on us in Ireland,  it's the only way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Hamish! Campbell! Divide  them and run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoving groups of men in different directions, Wallace th takes off. His group is about a dozen; they race through woods, dodging trees, running aimlessly. They stop and li The BARKS are getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Split again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again they divide, and race in different directions. But no matter how they run and dodge, the BARKS grow near We INTERCUT with the approaching of the dogs -- a large P OF HOUNDS, with keepers like on a fox hunt, and behind th dogs, Lord Pickering, with his soldiers, prepared for a l chase, cloaked against the wet darkness, carrying torches Wallace and others pause, hear the dogs, and run again, i new direction. The hounds are relentless. Wallace's group down to Hamish, Stephen, and Faudron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how we go, they follow.  They have our scent. My scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run! You must not be caught!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster now, faster. The barks are getting very close. Wallace and his friends are starting to panic. The blood  beats in their ears, their breath scalds their lungs. And MOVE IN on Wallace's eyes. He stops, gasping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've tricked us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the crazy man saying, Lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs have a scent. My scent.  Someone must have given it to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would do such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace pulls out his dagger...

dialogues.speaker: THE DOGS
dialogues.text: bark frantically now; they smell a kill; they tug so hard their leashes that the handlers are almost dragged along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be ready! We have them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers grip their weapons, ready to take their  prisoners. They burst into the little clearing; the dogs  find a body, stabbed, his throat cut; the dogs plunge the snouts into the gore, yipping wildly. The handlers must f furiously to tear the dogs from the body. Lord Pickering approaches the body and looks down. It is  Faudron, mangled now but clearly identifiable -- with the scarf he gave William, in place of William's own, tucked  into his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnation! Damnation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pickering rants, his men look at the darkness all arou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After him! Get them going again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their noses are drowned in new blood,  they'll follow nothing now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just as the realization hits Pickering that he can't  pursue Wallace any further, a cloaked figure mixed in amo his men leans in from behind him to whisper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Almighty says for you to give  His regards to the Devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pickering's eyes go wide, then roll back as Stephen's dag slides expertly through his back ribs and into his heart. Pickering falls and his men realize what has happened, St has already run back into the trees. Pickering's men freeze at this sudden turn of events. Eve the dogs whimper, picking up the rising fear of the men a them. Then from the darkness all around them comes a chor of demonic, bloodcurdling yells --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARRRRRGGGGGGGHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three wild men tear out of the darkness from different  directions, their swords slashing. Pickering's men panic run, their dogs yelping, and the other soldiers, evident their torches, fell with them in all directions. Wallace, Hamish and Stephen are left alone in the heart o the woods, howling, barking like dogs, snarling like wolv and then laughing like hyenas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was dead when ya pulled  that dagger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No English lord would trust an  Irishman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's kill him anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh again; then Wallace's laughter leaks away, and stares into the trees, where he saw Marion in his dream. VARIOUS SHOTS - THE STORY SPREADS THROUGH SCOTLAND... Two men are talking in A VILLAGE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and William Wallace killed fifty  men! Fifty, if it was one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same tale is exchanged by two farmers AT A CROSSROADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred men! With his own sword!  He cut a through the English like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tale is repeated IN A TAVERN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Moses through the Red Sea! Hacked  off two hundred heads!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw it with my own eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the rumors are discussed even INSIDE THE PALACE GROUN IN LONDON, where the Prince and his friends are trying on elaborate attire presented them by fawning tailors, and t Princess, ignored by her husband, strolls and chats with Handmaiden, Nicolette (in subtitled French).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the king returns he will bury  them in those new clothes. Scotland  is in chaos. Your husband is secretly  sending an army north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night I slept with a member of  the War Council.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shouldn't be telling secrets in  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Oui! Englishmen don't know what  a tongue is for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess blushes, whacks her with her fan, and smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Scottish rebel... Wallace? He  fights to avenge a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magistrate wished to capture him,  and found he had a secret lover, so  he cut the girl's throat to tempt  Wallace to fight -- and fight he  did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess is pained at such cruelty; Nicolette warms t share the juicy gossip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing his passion for his lost  love, they next plotted to take him  by desecrating the graves of his  father and brother and setting an  ambush at the grave of his wife. He  fought his way through the trap and  carried her body to a secret place!  Now that is romance, Oui?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Highlander, a RUNNER, slips like a shadow up the hillsi to a circle of ancient monoliths. There, hidden among the stone pillars, he finds Wallace and his band resting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English are advancing an army  toward Stirling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do the nobles rally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce and most of the  others will not commit to war! But  word has spread and Highlanders are  coming down on their own, by the  hundreds -- by the thousands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace rides down the road, followed by his band. As the pass people on the road, the women, the children, all che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace! It's William Wallace! God  bless Wallace and Scotland!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a crossroads, more of Wallace's men join them, in clus One group carries something long, encased in wool covers. Farmers in the field, blacksmiths at their forges, leave  their work and uncover their inevitable weapons and run a the riders. They put on their forbidden tartans, kiss the wives and head off to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stirling Castle perches on a hill high above a grassy fie cut in half by a river, spanned by an old wooden bridge. SCOTTISH NOBLES have gathered on a smaller hill overlooki the field; they wear gleaming armor, with plumes, sashes banners, and are attended by squires and grooms. The mists of morning shroud most of the field. But from t opposite side of the bridge they hear the CLATTERING of a huge army moving forward. LOCHLAN, a noble, gallops to Mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like twenty thousand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scouts say it is ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we have but two!

dialogues.speaker: THE COMMON SCOTTISH SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: are wearing padded leather shirts, and carry pikes and  daggers. As through the mists they see the numbers arraye against them, a YOUNG SOLDIER tugs at a grizzled VETERAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles will negotiate. If they  deal, they send us home. If not, we  charge. When we are all dead and  they can call themselves brave, they  withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come to fight so they could  own more lands that I could work for  them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor did I. Not against these odds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lowers his pike and starts to desert. At first one-by- and then in clumps, more highlanders follow. THE NOBLES see the desertion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Men! Do not flee! Not now!  Wait until we have negotiated!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't stop -- and who could  blame them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, riding into the mob of men, comes Wallace, followed his friends. He's striking, charismatic, his powerful arm bare, his chest covered not in armor but a commoner's lea shirt, and unlike the heavy knights on their armored hors Wallace rides a swift horse, like he was born on it. The entire Scottish army watches in fascination as Wallac and his men ride through them, toward the command hill. T soldiers whisper among themselves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Wallace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The common soldiers, already having broken ranks, cluster the hill to see the confrontation. As Wallace and his cap reach the nobles, Stephen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Almighty says this must be a  fashionable fight, it's drawn the  finest people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is thy salute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For presenting yourselves on this  battlefield, I give you thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our army. To join it, you  give homage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give homage to Scotland. And if  this is your army, why does it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace reins his horse around to face the mob of sullen  men, now frightened, ready to desert. We play this pictur Wallace sitting his horse, looking down in awe at this th that has grown beyond anyone's imagination. He glances at his friends: Campbell, Hamish, Stephen. They've got no suggestions, they're just as awed as he is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't come to fight for them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home! The English are too many!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace raises his hand, and the army falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sons of Scotland!... I am William  Wallace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Wallace is seven feet tall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have heard! He kills men by  the hundreds! And if he were here,  he would consume the English with  fireballs from his eyes, and bolts  of lightning from his ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many laugh -- all get the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am William Wallace. And my enemies  do not go away. I saw our good nobles  hanged. My wife... I am William  Wallace. And I see a whole army of  my countrymen, here in defiance of  tyranny. You have come to fight as  free men. And free men you are! What  will you do with freedom? Will you  fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand, against ten? We will  run -- and live!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Fight and you may die. Run and  you will live, at least awhile. And  dying in your bed many years from  now, would you be willing to trade  all the days from this day to that,  for one chance to come back here as  young men, and tell our enemies that  they make take our lives, but they  will never take our freedom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down on the plain, English emissaries in all their regal  finery gallop over the bridge, under a banner of truce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! The English comes to barter  with our nobles for castles and  titles. And our nobles will not be  in the front of the battle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! They will not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dismounts, and draws his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, the chant begins, and builds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! WAL-LACE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAGPIPERS play, pulling the mob back into companies. But  through the lifting mists they see the overwhelming enemy army. Hamish, Campbell and Stephen move up beside William

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine speech. Now what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring out our spearmen and set them  in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, Hamish and Stephen ride off. Mornay reins his h over, lifts the reins of Wallace's horse, and extends the to him: an invitation to join the pre-battle talks. Wallace mounts up and rides out with the Scottish nobles meet the English contingent.

dialogues.speaker: OUT ON THE FIELD, THE TWO GROUPS OF RIDERS
dialogues.text: meet like the captains of football teams before the kicko CHELTHAM, head of the English contingent, glares at Walla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornay. Lochlan. Inverness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheltham. This is William Wallace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are the King's terms. Lead this  army off the field, and he will give  you each estates in Yorkshire,  including hereditary title, from  which you will pay him an annual --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an offer for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...From which you will pay the King  an annual duty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace pulls his broadsword and snaps it at Cheltham, wh eyes flash in disbelief at the bad manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You disrespect a banner of truce?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his king? Absolutely. Here are  Scotland's terms. Lower your flags  and march straight to England,  stopping at every Scottish home you  pass to beg forgiveness for a hundred  years of theft, rape, and murder. Do  that, and your men shall live. Do it  not, and every one of you will die  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheltham barks at the Scottish nobles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are outmatched! You haven't even  any cavalry! In two centuries no  army has won without it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not finished. Before we let you  leave, your commander must cross  that bridge, stand before this army,  put his head between his legs, and  kiss his own ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outraged Englishman gallops back to his lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say that was rather less cordial  that he was used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be ready, and do exactly as I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They return to the Scottish lines. Wallace dismounts wher his men are breaking out new 14-foot spears. Hamish, eyeb raised, looks expectantly at Wallace; Wallace nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I could see the noble lord's  face when he tells him.

dialogues.speaker: LORD TALMADGE, AT HIS COMMAND POST
dialogues.text: The husky English commander's blood boils from Cheltham's report. Before he can respond, they see WALLACE'S SPEARME taking up a position on the far side of the bridge. Sudde the Scots turn and lift their kilts and moon the English!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insolent bastard! Full attack! Give  no quarter! And I want this Wallace's  heart brought to me on a plate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheltham spurs his horse to form up the attack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English army moves forward toward the bridge. It's so narrow that only a single file of riders can move across at any one time. The English heavy cavalry, two hundred  knights, cross uncontested, and form up on the other side

dialogues.speaker: WITH WALLACE AND THE SCOTS
dialogues.text: Things look terrible. Stephen turns to William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord tell me He can get me out  of this mess. But He's pretty sure  you're fooked.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ENGLISH SIDE
dialogues.text: Talmadge sees the Scots doing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amateurs! They do not even contest  us! Send across the infantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'lord, the bridge is so narrow --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots just stand in their  formations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our cavalry will ride them down like grass. Get the infan across so they can finish the slaughter! The English leaders shout orders and keep their men movin across the bridge. Talmadge gestures for the attack flag.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAVALRY ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The English knights see the signal banners, telling them attack. They take the lances from their squires, and lowe the visors of their helmets. Proud, plumed, glimmering; t look invincible. Their huge horses, themselves draped in  scarlet and purple, look like tanks. The knights charge! Their hooves THUNDER; the horses are so heavy the ground  literally shakes with the charge. The Scots stand and watch them come on. It's difficult to imagine the courage this takes; from the POV OF THE SCOTT LINES we see the massive horses boring in... we feel the  RISING THUNDER of the charge, closer, closer... Wallace moves to the front of the lead group of Scots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady! Hold... hold... NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots snap their 14-foot spears straight up in unison

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FORM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the spearmen snap the spears forward in ranks, the fi line of men bracing their spears at an angle three feet a the ground, the men behind them bracing theirs at a five  foot level, the men behind that bracing at seven feet. The English knights have never seen such a formation. The lances are useless and it's too late to stop! The momentu that was to carry the horses smashing through the men on  foot now becomes suicidal force; knights and horses impal themselves on the long spears like beef on skewers.

dialogues.speaker: TALMADGE
dialogues.text: can see it; but worse is the SOUND, the SCREAMS OF DYING AND HORSES, carried to him across the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE AND HIS MEN
dialogues.text: are protected, behind a literal wall of fallen chargers a knights. Wallace draws his broadsword and leads his sword out onto the field, attacking the knights that are still  alive. Most are off their horses; a few have managed to p up their mounts. Wallace and his men are so much more mob than the knights; the field runs with blood. Wallace faces Talmadge in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am, English coward! Come get  me!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TALMADGE is even more enraged -- and his judgment is gone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press the men across!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But M'lord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talmadge himself gallops forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRESS THEM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALLACE smiles. He grabs Hamish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mornay to ride to the flank and  cross upstream. Wait! Tell him to be  sure the English see him ride away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish hurries off with the message. The English infantry keeps moving across the little bridg The Scottish nobles watch from their positions on horseba They have a few dozen mounted riders, none heavily armore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he waits much longer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish hurries up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride around and ford behind them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should not divide our forces!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace says do it! And he says for  you to let the English see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding) They shall think we run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornay leads his riders away.

dialogues.speaker: LORD TALMADGE
dialogues.text: sees the Scottish nobles ride off, and shouts to Cheltham

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See! Every Scot with a horse is  fleeing! Hurry! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives half his army across the river.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE
dialogues.text: lifts his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Scotland!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He charges down the hill...

dialogues.speaker: THE FIGHT AT STIRLING BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The Scots follow Wallace on foot, charging into the Engli The English leaders are stunned by the ferocious attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press reinforcements across!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English leaders try to herd more of their footsoldier onto the bridge, which only hams them up. Meanwhile, on t other side of the bridge, Wallace and his charging men sl into the English infantry with wild fury. The English fal back on each other, further blocking the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE HILLTOP
dialogues.text: The nobles look back with grudging admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's taking the bloody bridge! The  English can't get across! He's evened  the odds at one stroke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With rising desire to join the bandwagon, the nobles spur DOWN ON THE PLAIN, Wallace and the attacking men drive th English back, killing as they go. The Scots reach the bri itself. The waters below it run red with blood. Talmadge has begun to panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use the archers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're too close, we'll shoot out  own men!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: the Scots are carving their way through the English soldi nothing can stop them. Wallace is relentless; each time h swings, a head flies, or an arm. Hamish and Stephen fight beside him, swinging the broadsword with both hands. Old  Campbell loses his shield in the grappling; an English  swordsman whacks at him and takes off his left hand, but  Campbell batters him to the ground with his right, and st him. Reaching the English side of the bridge, the Scots b to build a barrier with the dead bodies. The English are not without courage. Cheltham leads a  desperate counterattack. The Scots make an impenetrable  barrier of slashing blades. Still Cheltham keeps coming;  Wallace hits him with a vertical slash that parts his hel his hair, and his brain. TALMADGE has seen enough; he gallops away. The remaining  English General tries to save the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are still five thousand! Rally!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English try to form up; but the Scottish horsemen, fo the river high upstream, come crashing into the English f and ride over the surprised English infantry.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BRIDGE, WALLACE
dialogues.text: sees the Scottish nobles attacking. The English soldiers in utter panic, running and being cut down on all sides. And the Scottish soldiers taste something Scots have not  tasted for a hundred years: victory. Even while finishing off the last of the English soldiers, they begin their hi chant... Even the noblemen take up the chant! Wallace looks around at the aftermath of the battle: bodi on the field; soldiers lying impaled; stacks of bodies on the bridge; the bridge slick with blood. Before it can all sink in, William is lifted on the shoul of his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William kneels before one of Scotland's ancient elders, w lifts a silver sword and dubs William's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knight thee Sir William Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William rises and faces the Great Hall, crowded with hund of new admirers, as well as his old friends in their new  clothes and armor. The crowd chants --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace, Wal-lace!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace lifts his eyes, taking it all in. At the rear of hall is a balcony, backed by a magnificent sunlit stained glass window, and in the center of its rainbow corona he  sees a familiar form: Marion, so real to him in this mome of triumph that he can see her, glowing like an angel, in gown worthy of the occasion. But the illusion won't last; the blink of an eye she is gone, and Wallace hears the ch and fingers the cloth she gave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles of Scotland are gathered in the huge chamber; massive table runs across the far end of the room, and al on either side are the two rival factions of nobles, glar at each other. Old Craig is in the center, with young Rob the Bruce on his right. There is a general MURMUR along t nobles, and Robert whispers to Craig...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone know his politics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But his weight with the commoners  could unbalance everything. The  Balliols will kiss his ass, so we  must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A court STEWARDS steps in and formally announces...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lords of Scotland: Sir William  Wallace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles on each side of the table try to outdo each ot in their acclamation as Wallace strides in, flanked by Ha Campbell, and Stephen, splendid in their tartans. Old Craig rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir William. In the name of God, we  declare and appoint thee High  Protector of Scotland! And thy  captains as aides decamp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles rise; court attendants hurry to Wallace and dr a golden chain of office around his neck. Wallace takes t three smaller chains they bring and drapes them around th necks of his friends, as once again the nobles applaud. Almost before the applause dies, a member of the BALLIOL  clan, who has kept an open seat beside him, speaks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir William!! Inasmuch as you and  your captains hail from a region  long known to support the Balliol  clan, may we invite you to join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Wallace's gaze has locked onto Robert the Bruce, who  stares back, the two young lions instantly recognizing th leadership power of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are Robert the Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father fought in support of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Balliols shrivel. The nobles on the Bruce side can ba keep from grinning. Suddenly the men on the other end of table change their attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this new success, the result of  all of Scotland's efforts, now is  the time to declare a king!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are prepared to recognize  our legitimate succession!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the ones who won't support  the true claim! I demand consideration  of these documents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace glances again at the Bruce, who suddenly feels as of the bickering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those were lies when they were  written! Our documents prove  absolutely that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Wallace turns his back and walks toward the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir William! Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have beaten the English! But  they'll come back, because you won't  stand together. There is one clan in  this country -- Scotsmen. One class --  free. One price -- courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns again and strides toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... what will you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will invade England. And defeat  the English on their own ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invade?! That's impossible, it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace slings out his broadsword and moves down the leng of the table, bashing the succession documents into the l of the nobles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISTEN TO ME! Longshanks understands  this! This!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brandishes the broadsword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a difference between us.  You think the people of this country  exist to provide you with position.  I think your position exists to  provide the people with freedom. And  I go to make sure they have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace bangs through the door. Suppressing smiles, his  friends file out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace and his men are marching away, as Robert the Bruc runs out after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! ...I respect what you said.  But remember, these men have lands,  castles. Much to risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the common man who bleeds on the  battlefield, does he risk less?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But from top to bottom this  country has no sense of itself. Its  nobles share allegiance with England  and its clans war with each other.  If you make enemies on both sides of  the border, you'll end up dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all end up dead. It's only a  question of how. And why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace walks; Robert catches up and speaks to him in an  urgent half whisper, so that no one else can hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no coward! I want what you want!  But we need the nobles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobles? What does that mean -- to be  noble? Your title gives you claim to  the throne of our country. But men  don't follow titles, they follow  courage! Your arm speaks louder than  your tongue. Our people know you.  Noble and common, they respect you.  If you would lead them toward freedom,  they would follow you. And so would  I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace walks away, leaving Robert the Bruce alone.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOTTISH ARMY
dialogues.text: Wallace rides at the head of his army, moving through the countryside of northern England. It is autumn, the foliag is beautiful, the wheat fields gold with harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medieval city guarded by a fortress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROYAL GOVERNOR is a spoiled young man, Longshanks' ne He is studying maps and written appeals for help; his CAP of defenses strides in with another note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Message from your cousin, the Prince.  He says London has no more troops to  send.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every town in Northern England is  begging for help! Where will Wallace  strike first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should think these smaller  settlements along the border...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hear shouts as a rider arrives and dismounts. They l out to see a panicked RIDER, who shouts up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He advances!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as civilians flee the walled city in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOTTISH ARMY
dialogues.text: has cut a huge tree and placed it on wheels. It rumbles  ominously TOWARD CAMERA... THE CIVILIAN PANIC CONTINUES as more people join the swel of those leaving York. THE SCOTTISH ARMY keeps coming on.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE WALLS OF THE CITY
dialogues.text: The governor is furious and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will not allow a bandit to panic  the greatest city in Northern England!  Close off the escapes! Let no one  leave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city has emptied already, Sire.  Only the Scottish civilians remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor turns to his captain with a look worthy of h uncle, Longshanks the King.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BATTERING RAM
dialogues.text: as it picks up speed and SLAMS into the wooden gate of th city. With the collision, THE BATTLE IS ON. It's a night  battle: torches, flaming arrows, pots of boiling oil bein splashed down at the attackers, who swarm the gate. The oil beats the first wave of Scots back, but Wallace r forward, grabbing the ram cart with his own hands; the  attackers rally to him, helping him slam the gate again a again. It breaks; but behind it is an awful tangle of car broken sheds, impenetrable rubbish. Wallace grabs a torch throws it into the wooden tangle, and shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back! Wait for it to burn!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CITY
dialogues.text: The Captain hurries into the tower room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've breached the wall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do as I ordered.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE WALLS
dialogues.text: The Scots wait, biding their time as the barrier burns. Suddenly they look up in horror; the English are throwing the bodies of hanged Scots over the wall. They stare at this in mute shock. Wallace is frozen, his  eyes reflecting his boyhood reaction. His men rush forwar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOP! NOT YET! LISTEN TO ME! (beat) They wish to frighten us! Or goad us  into attacking too soon! Don't look  away! LOOK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots look at the hanging bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behold the enemy we fight! We will  be more merciful than they have been.  We will spare women, children, and  priests. For all else, no mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace draws his broadsword. The burning debris inside t gate collapses, leaving a tunnel through the fire. Wallac screams, and leads the charge through the burning barrier

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Edward and Phillip, his fencing friend and lover,  hear a contingent of horsemen clatter into the courtyard  below; they look out the window and see the arrival of  Longshanks. They lean back into the room and Edward begins to pace  nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not your fault! Stand up to  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward shows Phillip the dagger he has concealed in his b behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will stand up to him, and more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks bangs the door open and stalks in angrily. Fir he glares at Phillip with obvious loathing, then turns hi piercing stare to his own son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What news of the north?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing new, Majesty. We have sent  riders to speed any word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While I am in France fighting to  expand your future kingdom I learn  that Stirling castle is lost, our  entire northern army wiped out! And  you have done nothing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have ordered conscriptions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A messenger enters and hands the prince a message. Edward reads it and nearly loses his balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace has sacked York!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. (to messenger) How dare you bring a panicky lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The messenger has also brought a basket. He approaches th central table with great dread and places the basket on i uncovering its contents. Prince Edward is closest; he loo in, then staggers back, stunned. Longshanks moves to the  sack coldly, looks in, and withdraws the severed head of nephew, York's (former) Governor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire! Thy own nephew! What beast  could do such a thing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king drops the head back into the sack, unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he can sack York, he can invade  lower England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would stop him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward, who is this shitpoker who  speaks to me as if I needed his  advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have declared Phillip my High  Counselor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks nods as if impressed. He moves to Phillip and  examines the gold chain of office that the young man wear Then Longshanks grabs him and throws him out the window, same one Edward and Phillip were looking out, six stories above the courtyard. We hear Phillip's SCREAM as he falls Edward rushes toward the window in horror. He looks out a the result, turns back toward his father in shock and hat and only then remembers the dagger and goes for it. He stabs at Longshanks; the old king smiles at the attack parrying, letting his arms be cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fight back at last!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Longshanks unleashes his own hateful fury; he grappl with Edward, knocking the dagger away and hurling him to floor; then Longshanks kicks his son, again and again. He exhausts his fury on him. Edward is a bloody mess; Longshanks coughs up a bit of bl He ignores it and his son's wreckage, and goes back to th discussion, as if this fight was normal business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must sue for a truce, and buy him  off. But who will go to him? Not I.  If I came under the sword of this  murderer, I would end up like my  nephew. And not you, the sight of my  faggot son would only encourage an  enemy to take over this country. So  whom do I send?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks calculates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full encampment, across an English field; campfires cha the dawn chill. Soldiers sharpen swords and spear points. Wallace is huddled with his inner circle, all except Camp who receives a report from a scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A royal entourage comes, flying  banners of truce, and the standards  of Longshanks himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace buckles on his sword.

dialogues.speaker: AN ENGLISH PAVILION TENT
dialogues.text: Set up for a meeting in a sunny meadow. Wallace and his m ride in, wary, ready for ambush. They surround the tent. There are two dozen royal soldiers there, but they make n threatening moves. No sound from the tent. Wallace rests his hand on the han of his broadsword, ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks! I have come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Servants pull back the sides of the tent door, and a tall slender, shapely female figure appears there. There in th shadows, she looks just like Marion! William is not the o one who notices the resemblance; he glances at Hamish and Campbell and sees them haunted by it too. Is this another dream? He pales, as she steps into the morning sun. She m toward him, her face lowered. It is Marion! She reaches him, lifts her face... and he sees the Prince William is relieved -- and yet as he sees the Princess mo closely he is still shaken by the resemblance in the way carries herself, her shape, the fall of her hair. The Princess is struck with Wallace, too -- tall, powerfu and commanding. Wallace dismounts, and moves to face her. Their eyes hang on each other. She sees something that sh has not seen in the face of a man in her whole life. She surprises him by bending at the knee, in a half-submi yet proud curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Princess of Wales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wife of Edward, the king's son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods; somehow she is already ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come as the king's servant, and  with his authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's battle I want, not talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now that I am here, will you  speak with a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him under the pavilion, a purple canopy shading rich carpets laid on the bare ground. Watching the gorgeo walk, Stephen lies back on his saddle and twitches his le like a horny dog. Hamish backhands him; Campbell, Hamish Stephen quickly dismount and follow the procession,  shouldering their way in beside the Princess's French gua so they can watch Wallace's back. The rest of the Scots  surround the tent, ready for ambush. Nicolette is among the royal attendants there; seeing Wal she shoots a glance at the Princess that says Ooo-La-La! servants have brought a throne for the Princess, a lower  chair for Wallace. She sits; he refuses the chair. She studies him, taking in his anger and his pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that you have recently  been given the rank of knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been given nothing. God makes  men what they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did God make you the sacker of  peaceful cities? The executioner of  the king's nephew, my husband's own  cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: York was the staging point for every  invasion of my country. And that  royal cousin hanged a hundred Scots,  even women and children, from the  city walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But knowing Longshanks' family, she glances at a richly  dressed Advisor, a CRONY of the king, who averts his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks did far worse, the last  time he took a Scottish city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crony mumbles to her in LATIN, WITH SUBTITLES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Latin) He is a murdering bandit, he lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Latin!) I am no bandit. And I do not lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are startled at Wallace's fluency in Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or in French if you prefer that:  Certainmous et ver! Ask your king to  his face, and see if his eyes can  convince you of the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares for a long moment at Wallace's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton, leave us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'lady --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reluctantly obeys. Seeing that she wants the exchange be private, Wallace turns and nods for his men to leave. Stephen, who has been admiring the lady's beauty non-stop leans in and whispers to William...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband's more of a queen than  she is. Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen moves off with Hamish and Campbell. Wallace and t princess are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us talk plainly. You invade  England. But you cannot complete the  conquest, so far from your shelter  and supply. The King proposes that  you withdraw your attack. In return  he grants you title, estates, and  this chest with a thousand pounds of  gold, which I am to pay to you  personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Lordship. And gold. That I should  become Judas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace is made is such ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAVES ARE MADE IN SUCH WAYS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outburst startles even those watching from a distance The Princess is mesmerized by Wallace's passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you have suffered. I  know... about your woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was my wife. We married in secret  because I would not share her with  an English lord. They killed her to  get to me. And she was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess is stunned; Wallace is dead still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never told anyone. I don't know  why I tell you -- except because you  look... much like her. And someday  you will be a queen, and you must  open your eyes! (beat) Tell your king that William Wallace  will not be ruled. Nor will any Scot,  while I live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess rises slowly from her chair, moves in front him, and lowers herself to her knees. The Crony and her o attendants, seeing this from a distance, are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. I leave this money, as a gift.  Not from the king, but from myself.  And not to you, but to the orphans  of your country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts her face. Their eyes hold a moment too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace and his captains sit on horseback at the head of  their company and watch as the Princess' procession leave Hamish studies Wallace's face; Wallace notices and gives a non-committal shrug. As the carriage rolls away, its wi curtains lift back slightly. All they see are the Princes fingers, but they know she looked back. Wallace reins his horse away, to ride back to camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open; the Princess enters Longshanks' war counc Prince Edward is there, among a dozen others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son's loyal wife returns, unkilled  by the heathen. So he accepted our  bribe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why does he stay? My scouts say  he has not advanced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits. For you. He says he will  attack no more towns -- if you are  man enough to come fight him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spoke with this Wallace in  private. What kind of man is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A mindless barbarian. Not a king  like you, M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scottish nobles have sent him no  support. His army starves. Our stall  has worked, he must withdraw. You  may return to your embroidery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humbly, M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She barely curtseys, and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought back the money, of course?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He already knows she didn't; Hamilton is standing near hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I have it to ease the suffering  of the children of this war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at son) This is what happens when you must  send a woman. And a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Sire. I thought that  generosity might demonstrate your  greatness to those you mean to rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My greatness is better demonstrated  with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a box at his feet the king withdraws a crossbow and  throws it onto the table. Most of those there are shocked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weapon has been outlawed by the  Pope himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the Scots will have none of them,  will they? My armorers have already  made a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks smiles. No one notices that the Princess is de pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots are lining up to leave their encampment. Wallac is about to give the signal to start the march when Hamis beside him, comes alert; a small group of riders in  distinctive attire are coming toward them; what can this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William -- French guards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The riders stop at a distance, and out from their ranks c a single rider, sitting sidesaddle. It is Nicolette. Wallace and Hamish recognize her from the Princess's visi She trots her horse the rest of the way, while the French guards stay back. Hamish helps her from her horse. She mo to Wallace, and opens the heavy folds of her heavy riding cape. Secreted there, hung from a rope at her neck, is a crossb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace has gathered the nobles, among them Robert the Br Mornay, and old Craig, for a demonstration. Hamish and St have placed a spearman's chestplate against a bale of hay As William cranks the crossbow to its full cocked positio and places a bolt in its slot, Stephen tucks a melon behi the armor. William aims... and fires. The bolt slashes through the a and punches through the armor and the melon, leaving no d what it would do to a man's heart. The nobles pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is why the Pope outlawed the  weapon! It makes war too terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many does Longshanks have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand. (beat) You have made me Guardian of Scotland.  So I tell you this is what we face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must sue for peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot defeat this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With cavalry -- not heavy, like the  English, but light, fast horsemen,  like you nobles employ -- we could  outmaneuver their bowmen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir William --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bruce sees Wallace about to explode, and tries to  intervene -- but Wallace's anger is too great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won at Stirling and still you  quibbled! We won at York and you  would not support us! Then I said  nothing! Now I say you are cowards!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles grip their weapons; Wallace, Hamish and Stephe are ready to finish this quarrel right here. Robert the B backed by Mornay, steps between the two sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Sir William! Speak with me  alone! I beg you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles stalk away, and Robert draws Wallace away, to target Wallace shot, so they are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have achieved more than anyone  dreamed. But fighting these odds  looks like rage, not courage. Peace  offers its rewards! Has war become a  habit you cannot break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question strikes deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War finds me willing. I know it won't  bring back all I have lost. But it  can bring what none of us have ever  had -- a country of our own. For  that we need a king. We need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tell me what a king is! Is he a  man who believes only what others  believe? Is he one who calculates  the numbers for and against him but  never weighs the strength in your  own heart? There is strength in you.  I see it. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must... consult with my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will consult with mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce walks off the field, heading the way the other nobles went. Wallace rejoins Hamish and Stephen. Th look to him; what do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember when the English turned  their hounds on us? Maybe we should  introduce them to our dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the faint nimbus of the single candle, young Robert si across from his leper father. The son grips his own head, if stunned by a blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This... cannot be the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have said yourself that the nobles  will not support Wallace, so how  does it help us to join the side  that is slaughtered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heartsick, the father reaches across the table, then stay his arm, unwilling to touch his son with his leprous hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son. Look at me. I cannot be king.  You, and you alone, can rule Scotland.  What I tell you, you must do -- for  yourself, and for your country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Robert holds his father with his eyes, and does not look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scottish army moves out onto the hilly plain, covered the gray mists. They see glimpses of the enemy in the  distance. Wallace deploys the Scots: Campbell with the  schiltrons (spear formations), Stephen with the infantry, the noble Mornay leading the cavalry, and with Wallace an Hamish on horseback, looking over the field. Hamish sees  gazing up at an empty hill above the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bruce is not coming, William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornay has come. So will the Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd better, the odds look long. And it's nasty ground; o side of the field is ankle deep in water, and the English are covering it with a layer of burning oil, releasing th smoke to hide their movements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Priest from their home village is moving through the  Scottish ranks, dispensing absolution. He reaches the two friends, who accept the Host, say their own last prayers, and give each other a look of goodbye. Hamish rides off t join the schiltrons.

dialogues.speaker: LONGSHANKS AND HIS GENERALS
dialogues.text: on the opposite side of the field, send their army forwar

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE AND THE SCOTS
dialogues.text: see them through the smoke; Wallace spots what he's looki for: there they are, the ranks of crossbowmen! And as they draw nearer, Wallace hears a haunting noise. sees the bowmen more clearly, and the English infantry. S are wearing kilts and marching to bagpipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irish troops!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN OF IRELAND, WITH THE SCOTTISH INFANTRY
dialogues.text: He stares at the approach of his countrymen. Wallace appe beside him. Stephen sees him, and is ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's where Longshanks got his  soldiers. Irishmen, willing to kill  Scottish cousins for the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their families are starving, they'll  feed them however they can. If you  don't want to fight them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'll stand with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loyal to the end. Wallace signals to Hamish and Campbell, among the schiltrons. The formations, bristling with spea move forward. Hamish looks back at Wallace; both men know the spearmen are the bait here. Wallace and Stephen see t English heavy cavalry advancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't be that stupid to attack  the schiltrons again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace is scanning the battlefield. He sees the English  cavalry charge, but before they reach the bristling spear they pull up, and crossbowmen, moving up behind the knigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a faint to shield the  crossbows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crossbowmen fire a volley, too hurriedly. We see the  hailstorm of bolts slash through the air in unison -- you can actually see them coming. The bows fall short of the  front ranks of the schiltrons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Give 'em the dogs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen signals, and up the slope behind them come handle with ten war dogs. Huge mastiffs, they wear steel collars, with razor sharp  protrusions. Their handlers hold them at the end of long  catch poles. The crossbowmen are distracted from their  reloading by the appearance of the mastiffs; now, as the  Scottish handlers run toward the English ranks and unleas the dogs, fear races through the English line. The dogs tear into them. It is chaos; the bowmen can't fl and as the dogs mix among them, the bowmen fire frantical mostly hitting each other. The dogs' collars slash legs;  their jaws crush bones; even when their back legs are hac off, the frenzied dogs keep killing. Wallace signals to Mornay with the Scottish cavalry. Morn does nothing. The crossbowmen, though taking great punish are beginning to overwhelm the dogs by sheer numbers, and are regrouping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Charge! Charge them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornay tugs his reins and leads his cavalry away.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ENGLISH COMMAND
dialogues.text: Longshanks and his officers see Mornay and his cavalry me away. The English general looks knowingly at Longshanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For double his lands in Scotland,  and matching estates in England.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE, WITH STEPHEN
dialogues.text: They see the Scottish army abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betrayed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace glances to the other hilltop; still no sign of Br He looks on in agony as the crossbowmen unleash another  volley. The Scottish spearmen, bunched in a tight group, helpless. The bolts fall, cutting through their helmets a breastplates like paper. Wallace has no cavalry -- and hi men are being slaughtered! He spurs his horse, and Stephe and the infantrymen race behind him. The English heavy cavalry surge to meet them, but Wallace weaves through them, dodging with his horse, slashing wit the broadsword, cutting down on knight, another, another. The Scottish infantry claws in, dragging down the horses, hacking the knights as they run by. The English bowmen are about to fire again, but they see Scottish charge bearing down on them and adjust their aim the bolts cut into the infantrymen; one bolt tears off th armor of Wallace's left shoulder. He wobbles on his horse regains his balance, and keeps up the charge.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ENGLISH COMMAND
dialogues.text: Longshanks and his generals are watching the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, and still they come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use the reinforcements! But take  Wallace alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General signals and the English reinforcements surge  into the battle.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE THICK OF THE BATTLE
dialogues.text: On horseback, Wallace fights his way into the watery edge the field, where English infantry is now overrunning the  schiltron. He hacks men down left and right, reaches the  Scottish center, and finds Hamish bending over another  soldier. Wallace dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish! Ham --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Wallace sees that Hamish is holding his father, falle in battle. Wallace has no time to react; he cuts down and English swordsman moving in to hack Hamish's back. Wallac lifts Campbell across the saddle, and shouts at Hamish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish obeys, jumping onto the horse and galloping back t the rear. Wallace fights with new vengeance, swinging the double-edged broadsword with deadly accuracy. Rallied by Wallace's presence, the Scots surge back. Then Wallace sees the English reinforcement cavalry coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charge! Form up! Form up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots pull up spears and hastily form another schiltr The spears bristle out, ready... the English horsemen thu in. But before the spears impale the horses, another flig of crossbow bolts cuts down half the Scots still fighting Hamish reaches the rear of the battle and lowers the limp body of his father to the Scottish monks who are attendin to the wounded and giving absolution to the dying... Still Wallace fights back, meeting the English charge. Th Scots hold their own. An English knight tries to ride ove William; he knocks the lance aside, and tough the horse s into him, William also unseats the rider. The rider rolls to his feet. William struggles up to meet him -- and comes face to face with Robert the Bruce. The shock and recognition stun Wallace; in that moment,  looking at Robert the Bruce's guilt-ridden face, he  understands everything: the betrayal, the hopelessness of Scotland. As he stands there frozen, a bolt punches into muscle of his neck, and Wallace doesn't react to it. Bruce is horrified at the sight of Wallace this way. He  batters at Wallace's sword, as if its use would give him  absolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight me! Fight me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Wallace can only stagger back. Bruce's voice grows ra as he screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIGHT ME!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All around, the battle has decayed; the Scots are being  slaughtered. Another bolt glances off Wallace's helmet; a third rips into his thigh plate, making his legs collapse Suddenly Stephen comes through the melee, on Robert's hor He hits Robert from behind, knocking him down, and jumps the ground to try and lift William onto the horse! Robert sees a knot of crossbowmen moving up, sighting out Wallace, taking careful aim! Bruce leaps up and helps Ste sling Wallace onto the back of the horse, even covers him with his shield, deflecting another bolt fired at Wallace as Stephen mounts too. As the horse plunges away into the smoke, Robert falls to the water. His own troops reach him, realize who he is, s the horrible expression on his face, and race on after th Scots. Robert is left alone, on his knees in the water, the fire and noise of battle now dim to him, as if his senses have died along with his heart.

dialogues.speaker: LONGSHANKS
dialogues.text: Looks over the battlefield, strewn with the bodies of the Scottish dead. For now, he is satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remnants of the defeated army straggle past. Wallace and  Stephen are trying to help Hamish carry his father, but n old Campbell says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son... I want to die on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as they tilt old Campbell onto the ground, he grabs a something that starts to fall from the wound in his stoma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew. That'll clear your sinuses.  Goodbye, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're going to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can do without one  of those... whatever it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish is too grief-stricken to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... were like my father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Campbell rallies one more time for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And glad to die, like him... So  you could be the men you are. All of  ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last three words to Hamish, telling him he's a hero t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a happy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish is weeping. When he looks up again, his father has died. We PULL BACK from them in tableaux, with the army, people of Scotland, the whole gray world in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace, still bloody and in his battered armor, removes chain of office from beneath his breastplate, lays it ont the table in front of Craig and the other nobles, and wal from the room. Hamish and Stephen see the satisfaction on the nobles' face, and follow William out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamish and Stephen move out into the hallway after Wallac but he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace is in the woods, in the grove of trees, looking a Marion's hidden grave. The rain falls on his face, like t But he has no tears of his own. The cold, the icy rain, t wounds, nothing seems to touch him. With his fingertips he carefully draws her embroidered cl from beneath his breastplate; hanging in his trembling ha filthy with the grime and gore of battle, it looks imposs white, something from a better, purer world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder, the sound of driving rain. Snug by a massive fir are Longshanks, his son Edward, and other advisors. On th far side of the room, away from the fire, the Princess st at the window and watches the rain against the panes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their nobles have sworn allegiance,  M'lord. Every last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks savors the victory -- and gloats to his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we kill two birds at one stroke.  We recruit from Scotland for our  armies in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scots will fight for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What choice do they have? Now they  must serve us or starve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if we have not caught Wallace --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) He is gone! Finished! Dead! If he  has not yet bled to death or had his  throat cut for him, he will not  survive the winter. It is very cold --  is it not, our flower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the other side of the window, we see the Princess as she hears him, but doesn't turn around. She looks at the  window, we snow swirling among the raindrops outside. Her eyes glisten, and her breath fogs the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elder Bruce, his decaying features sagging from his f stares across the table at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the one who is rotting. But I  think your face looks graver than  mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was so brave. With courage alone  he nearly won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So more men were slaughtered  uselessly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He broke because of me. I saw it. He  lost all will to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must have alliance with England  to prevail here. You achieved that!  You saved your family, increased  your lands! In time you will have  all the power in Scotland!... Yet  you grieve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my heart I had begun to hope that  he would never break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men lose heart. All betray. It  is exactly why we must make the  choices we make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornay, in an opulent bedchamber hung with tapestries and carpeted with eastern rugs, lies in bed, tossing in the  restless sleep of a tortured soul. He thinks he hears galloping. In SUBLIMINAL FLASHES he DR of Wallace riding toward him. He wakes, and listens to a strange noise. It is hoofbeats Coming closer. He hears shouts too, screams from below -- and those strange, approaching hoofbeats...

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE, ON HORSEBACK
dialogues.text: rides up the circular stairs inside Mornay's castle! His  horse bounds up the stone -- Mornay's guards are behind h on foot, pursuing. At a landing, Wallace cuts down a guard, and gallops high

dialogues.speaker: IN HIS BED, MORNAY
dialogues.text: sits up gawking as the door explodes inward and Wallace r through! Mornay is frozen. Wallace slashes him down. Out in the corridor, the guards gather; they have Wallace trapped. He covers the horse's eyes with a cloth and spur his flanks. The blind animal runs through the window!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse and rider plunge past the sheer walls of the  castle... and into the loch! Mornay's guards and the cast servants cluster at the windows to see Wallace and the ho surface, and swim to the shore, escaping!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news has spread through the countryside. In the town  square, drunken Scotsmen chant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Craig rides past them, heading toward the Bruce's cas on the hill above the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is in his central room; he hears the chanting from far below. Old Craig enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true about Mornay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig hands him the bloody nightshirt Mornay was wearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he rode through the window? My  God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't hide his admiration. From below, he still hears people CHANTING...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks and Edward are in the royal gardens, resplende with spring. Longshanks pulls a new flower, and crushes i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His legend grows! It will be worse  than before!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let Wallace escape your whole  army. You cannot blame me for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks glowers at his son; the Princess arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day to you, M'Lords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
