dialogues.text: You mock us with a smile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am cheerful with a plan to soothe  your miseries. All of England shudders  with the news of renewed rebellion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace's followers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace himself. If you wish to  pretend a ghost rallies new volunteers  in every Scottish town, I leave you  to your hauntings. If you wish to  take him, I know a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward snickers in derision -- but his wife is steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have faced him. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will fight you forever. But what  does he fight for? Freedom first,  and peace. So grant them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little cow is insane --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant, as you do everything else,  with treachery. Offer him a truce to  discuss terms, and send me to my  castle at Locharmbie as your emissary.  He trusts me. Pick thirty of your  finest assassins for me to take along.  And I will set the meeting, and the  ambush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, my delicate son? I have  picked you a Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locharmbie is a small, picturesque castle on a hillside. the queen's entourage moves through the gates, they close behind her. She steps out of the carriage and moves into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the great hall are thirty killers, led by their CH ASSASSIN, a cutthroat with a mangled eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came in small groups, so the rebels  would not suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have reached Wallace's men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tell the villagers, and the  traitors pass it on. All that's left  is for you to say where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace is in the grove of trees where Marion is buried. Drinking in the silence, his own isolation. He hears a RU behind him, and spins, drawing the broadsword. Then his f registers... it's Hamish and Stephen. Hamish is unsure if he did the right thing in coming here unsure, until Wallace moves to them, and hugs them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in the old secret cave; rain is falling, but it' dry inside, with a campfire smoldering at the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the food and drink. And  for bringing 'em yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here to stay. We don't care to  live, if we can't fight beside ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen pulls a jug of whiskey from his pocket. He swigs, hands it to Hamish for a chug, then to Wallace, who decli but smiles for the first time in many weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is... one thing, William.  Longshanks is offering a truce. He  has dispatched his daughter-in-law  as his emissary, and she has sent  word that she wishes to meet you --  in a barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace frowns; a barn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hauntingly similar to the one in Wallace's childhood. As sits on his horse and looks at the place, surmounted by a white flag of truce, it gives him a chill. But in full vi of the barn, he hands Hamish his sword and rides forward.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BARN
dialogues.text: are the assassins, killing knives ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's William Wallace, sure! And...  he's given up his sword! Be ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They position themselves at every entrance.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE BARN
dialogues.text: Wallace reaches the barn, dismounts, and moves toward the door. But suddenly, instead of entering, he grabs the hea bar and seals the door! At this motion, Scots spring from the woods in all directions. The assassins inside realize the ambush is being turned on them, but it's too late; th hear the entrance being sealed from the outside. More Scots, led by Stephen, scramble up from hiding, plac tinder-dry brush and pitch against the barn, and set it o fire. In moments the entire barn is blazing. The Scots st back and watch the barn burn, their faces lit by the flam After awhile, there are no more screams from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess sees the burning off in the distance, like a bonfire. She stands on the wall, looking out at it. And t she sees, on a hillside, silhouetted against the night an the fire, a rider, just sitting there on his horse, looki at the castle. She runs into the castle, up the stairs, a stands on the pinnacle of the castle, so that she too is  silhouetted, and he can see her. The lone rider is William Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: A CANDLE
dialogues.text: being placed in a window of the stable cottage, built int the outer wall of the castle. AT A DISTANCE, the candle b like a tiny beacon. And William sees it.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE STABLE COTTAGE, THE PRINCESS
dialogues.text: sits alone, wondering if her signal is going to work.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Wallace climbs the castle wall, hand over hand up the mor stones, to the window twenty feet above the ground. He reaches the safety of the window cove and kneels on th ledge. He looks through the window, and sees her inside. INSIDE THE ROOM, she looks up, and sees him there. The fi glance frightens her, and yet she expected him, prayed fo him to come. Now, for a long, long moment the two of them look at each other through the glass, each realizing the  implications of this moment. She moves to the window and opens it. The wind rushing th extinguishes the candle, and he slips inside. They face e other in the darkness. Then she strikes a match and relig the candle, and they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meeting in a barn. It had to be a  trap. And only you would know I would  be aware of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does me good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am much diminished since we met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to say something -- but instead she says someth else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be a new shipment of  supplies coming north next month.  Food and weapons. They will trav --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Stop. I didn't come here for  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the way you're looking at  me now. The same way... as when we  met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his face away. Gently, she pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. You looked at me... and saw  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He twists back toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must forgive me what I feel. No  man has ever looked at me as you  did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised, he looks at her now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have... you have a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have taken vows. More than one.  I've vowed faithfulness to my husband,  and sworn to give him a son. And I  cannot keep both promises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, it starts to dawn on him what she's asking, and a unexpected smile plays at his lips. Her smile lights too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand. Consider, before you  laugh and say no. You will never own  a throne, though you deserve one.  But just as the sun will rise  tomorrow, some man will rule England.  And what if his veins ran not with  the blood of Longshanks, but with  that of a true king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot love you for the sake of  revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But can you love me for the sake  of all you loved and lost? Or simply  love me... because I love you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, he reaches to the candle flame, and pinches it ou

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SHADOWS OF THE COTTAGE BED
dialogues.text: we see the surging, pent-up passion... and

dialogues.speaker: THE LOVERS
dialogues.text: Their bodies limp, they lie asleep, entwined. The first r of morning spread yellow light through the room and acros their faces. Wallace wakes suddenly; sunlight! He grabs for his clothe as she wakes, covers herself in the blanket and jumps out bed, rushing to the window to look out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches her, throws the window open, and sees a clear  path down the wall to safety. He stops and looks at her, touches her face in gratitude. She has to ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we... did you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pausing to look straight into her eyes, he kisses her --  her, not Marion -- and climbs out. She watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace stands alone in the grove where Marion lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Wallace and fifty men gallop through a village on the to an English fortress; the villagers drop what they're d and run to follow them; we see Wallace's face, relentless as he hacks men down in the attack; with the fortress sac and smoking in the background, we see Wallace lead his me away, the people cheering him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, Wallace stares at the fire, beside his friend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest, William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your rest is making me exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen offers the jug; Wallace declines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, it'll help you sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. But it won't let me dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling a tattered tartan around himself, he lies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits by a palace hearth, where a huge blaze burns; sti he's huddled beneath a blanket, and coughing blood. But h ignores the ice in his lungs; his mind is plotting.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRINCESS, EXT. THE WALLS OF HER CASTLE
dialogues.text: she walks the parapets alone, lost in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT THE BRUCE, IN A STONE ROOM OF HIS CASTLE
dialogues.text: sits staring at... the stone coffin of his father. The co is closed; on its top is a lifesize stone carving of his  father as a knight in final repose. Ranks of candles ligh the scene, and Robert's face, cold as the stone. A SHUFFL Robert looks up to see old Craig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May he rest in peace... You have  already sealed the coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a modest man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will not be long before Longshanks  too is encased in stone, and his  crowns divided for others to wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig sits next to Robert, and keeps his voice low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our nobles are frightened and  confused... Wallace has the commoners  stirred up again, from the Highland  clans to the lowland villages. In  another six months Christ and the  Apostles could not govern this  country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert only stares at his father's stone coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks knows his son will scarcely  be able to rule England, much less  half of France. He needs Scotland  settled, and he trusts you, after  Falkirk. If you pay him homage, he  will recognize you as king of  Scotland. Our nobles have agreed to  this as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows Robert a parchment bearing the noblest names in  Scotland. The Bruce barely glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I pay homage to another's throne,  then how am I a king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homage is nothing. It is the crown  that matters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crown is that of Scotland. And  Scotland is William Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is another matter. There is a  price to all this, required both by  Longshanks and our nobles. Pay it,  and you will be our king. And we  will have peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert turns from his father's coffin, to look at Craig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commotion; the nobles, their heads hooded, are led in o horseback by guerrillas from the village. The nobles stop feel their hoods pulled off, and see Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir William. We come to seek a  meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've all sworn to Longshanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oath to a liar is no oath at all.  An oath to a patriot is a vow indeed.  Every man of us is ready to swear  loyalty to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let the council swear publicly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot. Some scarcely believe you  are alive. Other think you'll pay  them Mornay's wages. We bid you to  Edinburgh. Meet us at the city gates,  two days from now, at sunset. Pledge  us your pardon and we will unite  behind you. Scotland will be one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace glances at Hamish and Stephen, who can barely hid their contempt. Wallace looks at the nobles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will meet you, but only one way --  if Robert the Bruce is there, and  puts his hand on my Bible, and swears  his loyalty to Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has already agreed to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace stands alone, looking at the moon and stars. Hami moves up and sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it's a trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably. But we can't win alone. We  know that. This is the only way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a martyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I! I want to live! I want a home  and children and peace. I've asked  god for those things. But He's brought  me this sword. And if He wills that  I must lay it down to have what He  wants for my country, then I'll do  that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just a dream, William!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've lived a dream together. A dream  of freedom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dreams aren't about freedom!  They're about Marion! You have to be  a hero, because you think she sees  you! Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dreams of Marion are gone. I killed  them myself. If I knew I could live  with her on the other side of death,  I'd welcome it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, Hamish, and Stephen are on their horses, looking down at the road leading into the city. Wallace hands his dagger to Stephen, and unbuckles his broadsword and gives to Hamish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep these. We're going too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. One of us is enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace hugs them, first Stephen, then Hamish. Tears roll down Hamish's cheeks. With one last look at his friends,  Wallace rides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house looks quiet as Wallace rides toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce and Craig stand at the hearth, tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will. I know he will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hear the approach of a single horse. The Bruce looks out to see Wallace arriving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. And unarmed. My God, he has a  brave heart.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Wallace dismounts and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace appears at the doorway into the main room, and st Bruce faces him. The eyes of BOTH MEN meet, saying everyt Wallace steps into the room. He sees something flicker on Bruce's face -- shame -- just as henchmen in the rafters  drop a weighted net and it envelopes Wallace. English soldiers spring from the closets, run down the st and tumble over him, ripping at his clothes, searching as broadswords might spring from his boots. They bind Wallace hand and foot. He stares at Robert the  Bruce, who averts his eyes. The soldiers hurry Wallace ou the back, where others are bringing up horses. Robert gra the English Captain of the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not to be harmed. I have your  king's absolute promise that he will  be imprisoned only!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain looks at Bruce the way the High Priest must h looked at Judas, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we will have peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce spots something on the floor that must h fallen from Wallace's clothes as they grabbed him; Bruce  lifts the white handkerchief, and sees the familiar thist embroidered on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A procession of heavily armed English soldiers winds its toward London, Wallace strapped to an unsaddled horse, hi head bare to the sun. Country people come out to jeer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look so fearsome, does he?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thrown rock careens off Wallace's check; rotten fruit s his shirt. His lips are so parched they bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward inspects his father, who lies semiconscious in bed breath rattling ominously in his chest. Edward approves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess hurries up to her husband as he leaves the k bedroom, and follows him down the hall to his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true? Wallace is captured?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simply because he eluded your trap,  do you think he is more than a man?  My father is dying. Perhaps you should  think of our coronation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will his trial be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace's? For treason there is no  trial. Tomorrow he will be charged,  then executed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a faint smile, he shuts his bedroom door in her face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bruce is incredulous, yelling at Craig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks promised!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are surprised he would lie?  Balliol was murdered in a church  yesterday. You are Longshanks' new  designate. You will be king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace stands in medieval restraints worthy of Hannibal  Lecter. Before him are six scarlet-robed royal magistrate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Wallace! You stand in taint  of high treason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PUSH IN on the iron mask that binds his face. We can o see his eyes -- but they are bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treason. Against whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against thy king, thou vile fool!  Hast thou anything to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never, in my whole life, did I swear  allegiance to your king --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It matters not, he is thy king!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- while many who serve him have  taken and broken his oath many times.  I cannot commit treason, if I have  never been his subject!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confess, and you may receive a quick  death. Deny, and you must be purified  by pain. Do you confess? ...DO YOU  CONFESS?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not confess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then on the morrow, thou shalt receive  they purification... And in the end,  I promise you'll beg for the axe.

dialogues.speaker: THE TOWER
dialogues.text: The stone prison, and the wretched stone section known to this day as the Wallace Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace is alone in his cell, still in the garish restrai We can only see his eyes, as he prays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so afraid... Give me strength.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CELL DOOR
dialogues.text: The jailers jump to their feet as the Princess enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Highness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will see the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've orders from the king --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king will be dead in a month!  And his son is a weakling! Who do  you think will rule this kingdom?  Now OPEN THIS DOOR!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jailer obeys. The Princess can barely contain her sho at the sight of Wallace; the jailers snatch him upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your feet, you filth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Leave me! (they hesitate) There is no way out of this hell!  Leave me with him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly the jailers shuffle out of the cell, but they can still see her back and hear her. Looking at Wallace's eyes through the mask, she can't quite hold back her tear dangerous tears, that threaten to say too much. Wallace t to distract her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'lady... what kindness of you to  visit a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I... come to beg you to confess  all, and swear allegiance to the  king, that he might show you mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he show mercy to my country?  Will he take back his soldiers, and  let us rule ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercy... is to die quickly. Perhaps  even live in the Tower. In time, who  knows what can happen, if you can  only live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I swear to him, then everything I  am is dead already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to plead, she wants to scream. She can't stop t tears. And the jailers are watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your people are lucky to have a  princess so kind that she can grieve  at the death of a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She almost goes too far now, pulling closer to him -- but she doesn't care. She whispers, pleading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will die! It will be awful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every man dies. Not every man really  lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out a hidden vial, and whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink this! It will dull your pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will numb my wits, and I must  have them all. If I'm senseless, or  if I wail, then Longshanks will have  broken me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't bear the thought of your  torture. Take it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the verge of hysteria, she presses the vial to the air hole at his mouth and pours in the drug. The jailers, see suspicious movement, shift inside the cell; she backs up, her eyes wide, full of love and goodbye. From inside the  mask, he watches her go. When the door CLANGS shut, he sp the purple drug out through the mouth hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks lies helpless, his body racked with consumptio Edward sits against the wall, watching him die, glee in h eyes. The Princess enters, and marches to the bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come to beg for the life of  William Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fancy him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I respect him. At worst he was a  worthy enemy. Show mercy... Oh thou  great king... and win the respect of  your own people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longshanks shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even now, you are incapable of mercy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king can't speak. But hatred still glows in his eyes. The princess looks at her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor you. To you that word is as  unfamiliar as love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he lost his powers of speech,  he told me his one comfort was that  he would live to know Wallace was  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans down and grabs the dying king by the hair. The  guards flanking the door start forward but the Princess's eyes flare at them with more fire than even Longshanks on showed -- and the guards back off. She leans down and his to Longshanks, so softly that even Edward can't hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? Death comes to us all. And  it comes to William Wallace. But  before death comes to you, know this:  your blood dies with you. A child  who is not of your line grows in my  belly. Your son will not sit long on  the throne. I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets go of the old king. He sags like an empty sack b onto his satin pillows. Without even a look at her husban she strides out of the room, with the rattling breath of dying king rasping the air like a saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is festive; hawkers sell roast chickens, and be from barrels. Royal horsemen arrive, dragging Wallace str to a wooden litter. As they cut him loose and lead him th the crowd, the people begin to jeer and throw things at h chicken bones, rocks, empty tankards. We see a former English soldier, one of those who fled in terror at the battle of Stirling, lift a stone from the s and hurl it; it cracks against Wallace's cheek. Wallace's eyes capture the soldier, and hold him, piercin his soul. The soldier looks away in shame, even as the re of the crowd jeers more. Grim magistrates prod Wallace and he climbs the execution platform. On the platform are a noose, a dissection table with knives in plain view, and a chopping block with an  enormous axe. Wallace sees it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will use it all before this is  over. Or fall to your knees now,  declare yourself the king's loyal  subject, and beg his mercy, and you  shall have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He emphasizes "mercy" by pointing to the axe. Wallace is  pale, and trebles -- but he shakes his head. The CROWD gr noisier as they put the noose around Wallace's neck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- THE PRINCESS, in helpless agony, hearing the DISTANT N from her room in the palace... -- Hamish and Stephen, disguised as peasants among the cr helpless too, but there, as if to shoulder some of the pa -- Longshanks, rattling, coughing blood, as Edward watche -- Robert the Bruce paces along the walls of his castle i Scotland. His eyes are haunted; he grips the embroidered  handkerchief that belonged to Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE EXECUTION STAND
dialogues.text: a trio of burly hooded executioners cinch a rope around  Wallace's neck and hoist him up a pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it! Stretch him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the SCORE, AMAZING GRACE, wailed on bagpipes, carries  through all that happens now... Ties hand and foot, Walla is strangling. The Magistrate watches coldly; even when t executioner gives him a look that says they're about to g too far, he prolongs the moment; then the Magistrate nods and the executioner cuts the rope. Wallace slams to the  platform; the Magistrate leans to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasant, yes? Rise to your knees,  kiss the royal emblem on my cloak,  and you will feel no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With great effort, Wallace rises to his knees. The Magist assumes a formal posture and offers the cloak. Wallace struggles all the way to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well then. Rack him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The executioners slam Wallace onto his back on the table, spread his arms and legs, and tie each to a crank. Goaded the crowd, they pull the ropes taut. They crowd grows qui enough to hear the groaning of Wallace's limbs. Hamish an Stephen feel it in their own bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful, isn't it, that a man  remains conscious through such pain.  Enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace shakes his head. The executioners cut off his clo take hot irons from a fire box. The crowd grows silent; w see them, not Wallace, as the irons are touched to his bo but we hear the burning of flesh. Then the Magistrate sig Wallace wants to say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That... will... clear your sinuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone hears; Hamish smiles, even through his tears. Rebuffed, the Magistrate nods to the executioners, who li the terrible instruments of dissection. We are spared seeing the cutting: we are ON WALLACE'S FAC as the disembowelment begins. The Magistrate leans in bes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can all end. Right now! Bliss.  Peace. Just say it. Cry out. "Mercy!"  Yes?... Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd can't hear the magistrate but they know the  procedure, and they goad Wallace, chanting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mer-cy! Mer-cy! Mer-cy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace's eyes roll to the magistrate, who signals QUIET!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (booming) The prisoner wishes to say a word!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. Hamish and Stephen weep, whisper, pray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercy, William... Say Mercy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace's eyes flutter, and clear. He fights through the  pain, struggles for one last deep breath, and screams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREEEEE-DOMMMMMM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shout RINGS through the town. Hamish hears it. The  Princess hears it, at her open window, and touches her tu just showing the first signs of her pregnancy. Longshanks and his son seem to hear; the cry STILL ECHOES as if the  wind could carry it through the ends of Scotland; and Rob the Bruce, on the walls of his castle, looks up sharply, if he has heard...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LONDON SQUARE
dialogues.text: the crowd has never seen courage like this; even English  strangers begin to weep. The angry, defeated magistrate g a signal. They cut the ropes, drag Wallace over and put h head on the block. The executioner lifts his huge axe -- Wallace looks toward the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Hamish, eyes brimming, face glowing...

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: begins to drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the last half-moment of his life, when he has already  stepped into the world beyond this one, he glimpses someo standing at Hamish's shoulder. She is beautiful, smiling, serene. She is Marion.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT THE BRUCE
dialogues.text: His face has changed. He is standing AT THE OPEN GRAVE WH MARION LAY, the headstone carved with the thistle still t He holds the handkerchief. As he tucks it into his own po and we MOVE IN on his eyes, we realize the VOICE OVER bel to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the beheading, William Wallace's  body was torn to pieces. His head  was set on London bridge, where  passerby were invited to jeer at the  man who had caused so much fear in  England. (beat) His arms and legs were sent to the  four corners of Britain as warning.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We see the people, as the remains of William Wallace are  displayed in a box. The faces of the young men are fiery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did not have the effect that  Longshanks planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More young men put on tartans, take up their weapons, and gather into fighting units. Among them is Hamish, carryin shield emblazoned with a cocked arm holding a broadsword, and the words "For Freedom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce, flanked by the noblemen and the banners the Scottish throne, and backed by a ragtag army of Scots sits on his horse and looks down at the English generals their martial finery. The English are haughty, victorious at the head of their colorful, polished army, awaiting th ceremony of submission from Scotland's new king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I, Robert the Bruce, backed by a  body of Scottish veterans, rode out  to pay homage to the armies of the  English king, and accept his  endorsement of my crown.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BELOW, ON THE OPEN PLAIN
dialogues.text: The Scots -- the remains of William Wallace's army -- loo so ragged and defeated that it hardly seems worth the wai One ENGLISH COMMANDER turns and jokes with another...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you washed your ass this mornin --  it's never been kissed by a king  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP ON THE HILL, Robert the Bruce sits on his horse, and w He looks down at the English generals, at their banners,  their army. He looks down the ranks at his own. He sees Hamish. Stephen. Old MacClannough is there, his e watery, his weapon sharp. The Scottish bride Lord Bottoms took is there, among the ragtag archers, her husband besi her. Robert knows none of them -- yet he knows them all. Old Craig, among the other Scottish nobles mounted beside the Bruce, grows impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, let's get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Robert holds something -- uncurling his fist, he look at the thistle handkerchief that belonged to Wallace. The nobles start to rein their horses toward the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert the Bruce tucks the handkerchief safely behind his breastplate, and turns to the Highlanders who line the hi with him. He takes a long breath, and shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have bled with Wallace! Now bleed  with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce's broadsword slides from its scabbard. A cry rises  from Highlanders, as from a tomb, rising --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chant builds to a frenzy; it shakes the earth. The  Scottish nobles can scarcely believe it; the English are  shocked even more. Robert the Bruce, king of Scotland, sp his horse into full gallop toward the English, and the  Highlanders hurl their bodies down the hill, ready to run through hell itself. In SLOW MOTION we see their faces... And OVER THIS, we hear the voice of William Wallace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the year of our Lord 1314, patriots  of Scotland, starving and outnumbered,  charged the fields of Bannockburn.  They fought like warrior poets. They  fought like Scotsmen. And won their  freedom. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Wallace's army behind Robert the Bruce, charging down hill to victory and glory, we slow to FREEZE FRAME and he their chant, huge, echoing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!
